149618341.review:
You know, Amnesia is a much smarter game than a lot of people - myself included - gave it credit for. It's an incredibly limited game, but it spreads what few ideas it has frugally enough to trick you into thinking it's something it's not. See, Amnesia isn't a horror game - not really. 

It's just Myst. Seriously, this game is way more of a first person puzzler that uses it's atmosphere and exploration to tell a creepy Halloween story than it is a proper horror game, but it drenches the puzzles in enough mystery, darkness, and gore to hide that unless you really pay attention. The atmosphere is so oppressive and horrifying that you forget that there's no real bite to anything happening, mechanically. There's only a handful of encounters with monsters in the game where you have to hide and navigate around them to complete puzzles. Most of the time, you're walking around completing puzzles free of any monsters at all, but the developers smartly implement just enough instances of monsters suddenly appearing or jumpscares to keep you on your toes. This may be a section with no monsters at all, and it may be a section where a Brute appears around a corner and makes your heart rate jump through the roof. You won't really know until you're done and out of the area. Most of the tension is complete smoke and mirrors, with no real threat present, and when threats do present themselves they're trivial to navigate around.

All of that may disappointing at first - and I at first did find it disappointing - but it greatly works in the game's favor. The game's combat mechanics are nonexistent and the stealth mechanics aren't meaty enough to carry the game on it's own, which means that if you had been stopped by monsters every few feet while trying to navigate any given area to complete a puzzle, it would quickly become more frustrating than scary (looking at you, Outlast). So Amnesia spreads it's monster encounters thinly and ensures player death is incredibly sparse to prevent the tension from dissipating, while keeping tension high with great sound design and sanity effects that are used just enough to remain interesting without becoming overly distracting. Amnesia then spots areas with enough lore tidbits to keep you invested in the story that, while simple, is sold incredibly well with surprisingly excellent voice acting and pacing. The final piece of the puzzle is the length - Amnesia, like most horror games, is very short, and honestly depending on how good your puzzle-solving chops are you could likely finish this in a single sitting. It ends right when it needs to, right when the boring running and hiding is really beginning to wear through the veneer the game presents. It knows when it's done everything it can with the limited set of mechanics present, and leaves you before it become tedious. 

It's incredibly impressive, and while I may sound like I'm giving damnation by faint praise I genuinely mean it. Amnesia knows it's weaknesses present from it's core concept, and instead of trying to shore them up by adding what would've been limp-wristed, boring combat or exhausting the player with repetitive adrenaline pumping hide and seek sections (once again, looking at you, Outlast)  it instead narrows it's vision and delivers a tightly directed, incredibly focused experience. I would never call Amnesia one of my favorite horror games, but I respect the hell out of Frictional Games for their smart use of scorched earth game design here. If you've never played it and you're into horror games, I would definitely recommend giving it a go.

I have been aware of Frictional Games since the first Penumbra Tech demo came out.  I've always been a big fan of adventure games.  They are probably the only kind of game I'm likely to play all the way to the end.  I love solving puzzles to advance a plot.  The plot makes you care about the puzzles and the puzzles keep the plot fun.  To me it's the perfect kind of game.  Well, a lot of sites that like adventure games really were interested this Penumbra Tech demo and the kind of physics based puzzles it made possible.  Aren't we all getting tired of combining items in our inventory?  I certainly was.  I missed the greater variety of puzzles text adventures had and was going back to those rather than play another identical half-finished game from Microids.  So, I was excited to try this Penumbra Tech demo, and I enjoyed.  When Penumbra Overture and Penumbra Black Plague came out, I enjoyed those too.

And then Amnesia came out....  Now, I'm no adventure game purist, I'm okay with cross genre affairs.  I'll happily play an action-adventure Tomb Raider type game, or a puzzle platformer.  I was happy with the frights, here and there through the Penumbra games; the worm sections were by far the scariest parts and yet they felt so clever to me and will always be what I think of when I think of those games.  But Amnesia it is just barely relenting terror from the first scene.  Going to a new room is a loathsome task because you know it will be too dark to get your bearings and there is bound to be something in there with you.  Because of the premise revealed by the title, your goal is not something you feel particularly motivated to achieve.  If I were really in this situation, I would choose to leave by one of the windows and contact the police.  I certainly wouldn't be going below ground level where they might be no way back.  Not too long into the game, I said, why am I putting myself through this?  And I turned of the game and forgot about it.

Then Soma came out and I was lured back to Frictional games by a sci fi plot and an underwater setting.  I suppose it was a horror game, it did have monster, but Soma's monsters weren't too scary, less scary than the Penumbra fauna, in my opinion.  I was able to finish that and enjoy the game despite them, in fact they probably livened things up a bit.  Then I didn't really think about Frictional games for a while.  Their next game was a sequel or a prequel to Amensia, I wasn't interested in that.  But then I got that prequel/sequel (companion) in a humble bundle.  It wasn't what I was going after in the bundle, so I left it be until right now this Halloween 2023.  I thought, I should play horror game since I'm still up and everyone else is in bed and I should celebrate the holiday.  I loaded up Amnesia: Rebirth.

I loved it.  (At least what I've played so far)  I was far more invested in the main character and her story than I was with this gormless Daniel of the first Amnesia game.  And what was happening to the woman from Rebirth had surprising developments right from the first couple of scenes.  Plus, I enjoyed that it was more sci-fi than supernatural.  It didn't have much for puzzles in the part I was playing, and it was barely scary.  It felt more like a walking simulator, than an adventure or horror game, but that was fine.  I mean I've hated most walking simulators, but that's mostly because even a story is usually barely present.  Rebirth, as I say, had a fascinating story.  But as I decided I liked that game a feeling of cheating came over me.  I've never finished Amnesia, what do I think I'm doing playing this sequel?  I ruin all the surprises of the plot of the first one.  Already, I've discovered that apparently the mystery of Amnesia is going to be rooted in science fiction rather than fantasy....

So, I clicked exit game on Amnesia: Rebirth and downloaded Amnesia again.

I just hate this game.  Oh my gosh.  Why would anyone choose to put themselves through this?  It's just what I said before.  It's just looking in dark rooms of difficult to determine size, while at any moment something awful might happen to you.  There are really puzzles.  It's more just searching searching searching for whatever might serve as a key to the next area, all while trying to conserve your lantern oil and match sticks.  Good grief.  I think I'm about half way through the game at this point.  I suppose it is related to Rebirth in that there is some backstory about an archaeological expedition that uncovered some orb that I suppose is related to the things the woman in Rebirth is finding in her caves,  but my goodness, these little drips of information come so sparingly.  What reward is there for pushing on?  You finish one murky area, running at the last minute from some unholy monstrosity and the next thing you have to do is head through the next door for more of the same.  (By which I don't mean the game is repetitive.  Maybe it is a little bit, in the broad strokes.  But it's generally been pretty creative with just what the horrible thing is.  What you do in the water area, for instance, is much different from you do in the prison)

I don't know who this game is for.  It's not for me.  I want to be driven forward by satisfying my curiosity, not by, I suppose, proving I have a steel will.  To an extent, if I continue and finish the game, I suppose that curiosity will be what pushes me forward, but more for what it will reveal to me for when I return to Rebirth, than whatever I hope to find in this game.

But do I recommend it?  Well, if you know that this is a scary game and that is the whole point of it, and you think that sounds like a good time, then yes, I highly recommend it.  I don't think you could possibly do any better.  

If I can bring myself to play more of this game tomorrow, perhaps I will update this review.  If I can't play more of this game tomorrow, I suppose I will just move on to sunnier fields.

[h1]My name...is Daniel...[/h1]

[b][u]PROS[/u]:[/b] Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a horror title that plays it's best with atmosphere.  Getting that out of the way first, the game is dark in terms of it's story & visuals.  The areas of the castle send a feeling of unease, even in the quieter 'safe rooms' that act as smaller hubs.  The sound design only amps this up, not just with little nuances like additional footsteps, but different noises for each area that fill a sense of dread turning the corner.  As for the story, the player fills the amnestic shoes of Daniel, a man heading into the castle with a self imposed task of killing the castle's baron, Alexander.  The rest is filled out through notes & memories to piece together the actual reasons for being there.  The gameplay itself gives no way to defend, other than hiding.  A sanity meter exists alongside health, with the game's enemies & events damaging & drawn to a lowered state of sanity, being able to regain it by staying in light.  This keeps the experience tense throughout, not knowing what will come in the next area.  The game also comes with a selection of short stories & a DLC chapter titled Justine, unrelated to the main story, but short enough to provide a fun little jaunt.

[b][u]CONS[/u]:[/b] The game can be quite brutal in certain areas once monsters appear.  At times, it can be difficult to tell if Daniel is hidden well enough to be properly ignored by them.  The main hiccup the game has is the title's hard mode.  While in the main game constantly finding sources of light can be fairly trivial if one knows where to look, hard mode severely decreases the amount of ways to light one's path by lowering the available collectables, removes autosaves, & requires a stock of inventory items to save the game, alongside making it so the player dies if sanity decreases completely.  This turns the game into a stop & go experience that may require trips back & forth to safe zones just to regain sanity, dragging the pace of the game to a crawl.

[b][u]ACHIEVEMENTS[/u]:[/b] Though many are gotten just for clearing The Dark Descent & Justice, alongside their 3 endings each, a set are reserved for failing a task, & certain collectable hunts.  The notes must be collected in both titles, though the diary entries don't count for that total for some reason.  In addition, there are 151 tinderboxes in the main game that must be be collected in a playthrough for an achievement.  This can be tedious, as some of them are very well hidden.  Finally, the hard mode is a chore to complete, as stated above, & can actually be more difficult than hunting all the collectables due to requiring knowledge of collectable locations in the hopes they spawned, which very few do.  Lifting the lantern up & down is the best way to maintain sanity from the darkness, & this just adds to the tedium.

[b][u]FINAL[/u]:[/b] Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a wonderful, unsettling, & terrifying horror title that may not have been the first of it's kind, but kickstarted an array of horror titles of a similar kind for years to come.  This is a tentpole game in the genre, & deserves to be played by anyone curious on it.  Even over ten years later, this title still holds up.

I could point you to the survival horror genre that this title was a landmark for. Name a survival horror game post 2010, they inspired themselves with it.
I could point you to how much dreary detail and evils lurk beneath each note that so many left behind. If there's one thing you should take away from this, its this: Explore and be thorough. You will find more useful items and lore that is truly truly worth it.
I could summarize a brilliant story that reveals to you, bit by bit, evil, guilt and maybe, just maybe, redemption. The most you can hope for is truly disturbing imagery and darkness, ever encroaching darkness. It seems like the worst part, but you will find it's something far scarier than an enemy.
Or I could tell you to put on the lights if you fear getting through it for years, like I did. There's no shame in consuming guides if that's what it takes. Or having a friend guide you, like I did.

Will it prepare you for Amnesia: The Dark Descent? Probably not.
You play as Daniel, a man we initially know precious little about, and not in a good way either. We are in a castle that would probably be cozy, if not of the atmosphere and sound around us. We soon find out Daniel fears the dark and there's something... more to this. We explore the hallways and rooms, finding notes to help us make sense of this world. Soon enough we find a note to self. It tells us that:
We chose to forget how we ended up here.
We must kill Alexander of Brennenburg
A Shadow is chasing us, a living nightmare.
With that we begin our dark descent.

The gameplay unravels with ponderous but constant pace. You have your stats, inventory, health... and sanity. Pretty soon we are introduced to some of the strongest sides of the game: The light/dark interplay with sanity. You gain sanity by progressing in game. You lose it by witnessing disturbing events, staring at enemies and staying in the dark. You're told the lower the sanity, the harder it is to deal with enemies. That they'll be alerted if it drops to zero. Sanity alters your perception of reality as it drops: your vision gets blurry and distorted, portraits and other objects change form, hallucinations escalate, sometimes you even hallucinate enemies. On top of the excellently made atmosphere, it can make your play a living hell indeed.
 As you progress, if you are thorough, you find tinderboxes to light up torches and candles, and lamp oil for your mobile lantern. You will also find notes to further explain the setting. Much stress will result from the dilemma of preserving sanity or expending the lamp oil with your lantern and/or tinderboxes.

The game rewards those who dare to risk sanity-harming events. You'll find more useful items and be able to appreciate the story more. It is best played cautiously, fearfully, diligently. As you progress, the game will introduce enemies to you: First meekly and from far away, but don't let it deceive you: Half the horror in game comes from your inability to fight the enemies. You can only hide and wait till they leave. You have options: Will you lose sanity to hiding in the dark, turning your fear into your friend? Depending on situation, you'll be trying to hide in rooms, in the dark, be as far away as possible, or will have no choice but to run away in harrowing chase. An occasional puzzle will bring some variety. The game is divided into many levels. It starts linear, but then introduces hubs, from where batches of levels are available to be tackled in any order, barring prequisite items to unlock access. As you proceed towards your goal and explore, the veil of amnesia will slowly wear off. You'll slowly realize who Daniel is, what was he up to, and the motivations and artifacts of those around him. This game features some of the most depraved and inhuman characters around, and to your and Daniel's distress, their works will be expressed here. On your journey, the Shadow, manifested in fleshy residue, will continue to follow you, as if chasing you. Without spoiling too much, let me just say: It is not an enemy. It's something arguably worse.

The evils we witness, the atmosphere, the constant and heavy sense of dread, would not be possible without a stellar sound design. Mikko Tarmia has crafted the OST with loving care, and the sounds you hear all make the horror of it all possible. The events we witness (from mere gust of wind to The Shadow going ham somewhere), the hallucinations of Daniel (there's gonna be plenty of that), even psychic attacks: The game revels in trolling you and teasing you with threat of danger, making you scare yourself, especially when it'd only make things worse. Yet much like the darkness, sound design will be your asset. The enemies are loud, and sound will be your main way to locate them.

The presentation is clearly from early 2010s, with pitiful but servicable textures for these days, and lighting from that era as well. It has its charm and will not stand in the way of you being engaged.
You will witness damp rusty sewers, castle hallways, storage areas, all in the usual rustic castle style. But as you progress, you witness spaces that are either beautiful, claustrophobic and disturbing, or otherworldly in its presentation. Machinery fitting 19th century will often be seen, and be object of progression or puzzles.

This is the game where danger lurks when you don't know what you're doing, but this fear can be overcome. As you go, you will start to know what you're doing, and how to handle encounters. You will harden, but the depravity of what you witness will only escalate. In the end, you will truly have made your dark descent, into what defined Daniel's misery. Will you turn your thoughts to vengeance? Or something more?

A maddening, but ultimately sublime experience. Face a game that made history of the genre. Unveil guilt and hearken for redemption as your sins pile up. Know no defence against the enemy, and be pawn of powers beyond humanity. Relive nightmares. Become afraid of the dark in your own home. Become a lamb for futile sacrifice. Help someone and maybe be helped. Settle a debt and conquer your fears. All this and more in Amnesia: The Dark Descent.
A few tips:
-I feared wasting tinderboxes and lamp oil more than any monster and got my ending with 10 lamp oils and about 30 tinders. Such supply is a peace of mind more than anything.
-Be aware of places to hide in case encounter happens. They're scripted. 
-Play with your headphones, or whatever will easily indicate direction of sounds. You'll need it for enemies.

I decided to pick up the game again 12 years later. The reasons were curiosity (if the game is still as terrifying as it was at the time), fascination with the story (even though I know little), and also because of this remarkable experience of mine as a teenager. After finishing the game, 12 years later, I share here the following updated findings with great sincerity and impartiality. First, we start with the [b] GRAPHICS [/b]. The game is a little dated, and for that I implemented a remaster made by a fan, which is widely used and known by the community, which gave the game an excellent upgrade compared to the original. Without a doubt, it doesn't compare to today's graphics and mechanics, but nothing that hinders your experience. The game is perfectly playable nowadays, not to mention that the lack of light in the game helps and alleviates a lot in terms of level of details, especially those with greater distance.

Now the second factor, [b] ATMOSPHERE [/b]. I don't think any other horror game I've played until this day compares to Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Perhaps Resident Evil (the 1st Remake) and Silent Hill 2 are the closest, but it really involves another complexity. The game is too dark. It has extremely uncomfortable ambient sounds, such as screams of torture, children's cries, creaking wood, footsteps and agonizing moans. Something truly diabolical. Resources, especially oil, are scarce in the game, and must be used in moderation, which induces the player to perform actions with a certain anxiety and accelerated pace, making you “throw yourself” into the unknown and macabre environments of the scenario without know what awaits you. Finally, something that doesn't get talked about much and deserves real applause and recognition. The soundtrack... the game's soundtrack/sound effects are simply FANTASTIC. They fit perfectly with each segment of the game. Moments of hope, terrifying moments, characters, environment, chase, complete mastery.

Third factor, atmosphere. I don't think any oth... oops... I just remembered, that was already written... now is the part where we will deal with the [b] ENEMIES [/b] of the game. The monsters.... ahhhh the monsters... how to define them? They are horrible, grotesque, with bizarre movements and soul-shuddering sounds. Add this to the darkness and the environment around you and the impact is powerful. To this day, I believe that no other creature has ever given me such chills. Furthermore, they do not appear so frequently, a factor that means that the quality of construction of moments is prioritized, causing greater apprehension and anxiety. This entire set makes each encounter desperate, unpredictable and remarkable. As you progress through the game, you will better understand how the mechanics and stealth through monsters work, reducing the tension level a little and increasing your confidence and courage.

Fourth and penultimate factor, [b] ENVIRONMENT/SETTING [/b]. Here, in my opinion, is where the game's creators rocks. The game takes place in 1839, in Brennenburg Castle, Prussia. This era has a lot of historical inspiration from the Middle Ages and the Enlightenment. The level of creativity and intelligence to set a horror game in an ancient era with historical involvement is brilliant! An extremely rich idea, opening up a river of possibilities and elements that were masterfully introduced into the game. A dark and gigantic castle, lamps, candles, books, potions, tonics, paintings, chains, barrels, everything perfectly placed. Imagine a time when science was moving in short steps... everything was uncertain, mysterious. Science or Witchcraft? Alchemy or Magic? All concepts were hypothetical, undefined. All this air of mysticism can be defined as a touch of elegance introduced to the game. All historical elements and settings are the foundation, the soul of the game that encapsulates all the previously mentioned terror and atmosphere.

Finally, [b] STORY/CHARACTERS [/b]. I can't believe I've come this far..., but I must continue with courage and determination to finish my review. The game takes place only in the castle, but the story begins long ago before the game. Thanks to the amnesia, the game captivates us to look for all the pieces of the puzzle with determination and enthusiasm. Why we woke up like this, why we have to kill the castle baron, why horrible things happened, and so on. Loaded with guilt and remorse, but with convictions and steely courage to determinedly achieve redemption and the incessant search for good at all costs. Antagonist or Protagonist? Villain or Hero? Alexander is the man who sets out to help Daniel with his curse, offering his knowledge and technological advances in exchange for his service. But why then should we kill him? Should we kill the only man who offered us help? You will have to unravel these questions on your own... So I wish you good luck on your journey to discover the truth.

For me, it's the most iconic horror game in gaming history. If not, it is undoubtedly on the same shelf as Resident Evil and Silent Hill 2. My passion aside, it has been and continues to be chosen, by the general public and critics, as one of the best horror games in the gaming history and also the scariest game ever made. This is exactly how you make a horror game.

It is not a surprise that this game is great, spooky and very well done.
This game started many careers for so many people and was one of the scariest games back then for its atmosphere, use of the different light sources, story, mysteries and enemies.
While this game hasn't age too well in terms of visuals, for its time it was very good.

What truly makes this game so great is the different items that you get through the game, such as tinderboxes or oil, and you have them in your inventory, where you can also check your notes, health and sanity.
These make the game feel more alive, with sanity being an extra to make the game a bit more difficult if you experience some bizarre events, like doors opening by themselves or just by looking at enemies.
I wish there were the shortcut keys from Penumbra, but that's just a minor nitpick or missopportunity they could have added.

The game also plays very well with the sounds and the flashbacks from Daniel.
I also have to mention how you need to explore every room completely to find tools to progress through the game, and how sometimes you also need to backtrack a little bit.
There are also some pretty decent puzzles for some variety.

The monsters are very cool and spooky too and definitely one of the highlights from this game, while they can be buggy at times and maybe they are not as interesting as the ones from Penumbra, they feel accurate to how the game was made and its story.

And speaking of stories, this game has custom stories that people can make on their own!
I am surprised this game even had that for a game that was released in 2010, with a fairly easy to use level editor that is super intuitive.
Lots of custom stories are memorable such as House of Creep or The Great Work, or even some troll custom stories.
It was such an amazing idea that made a very dedicated community.

This game also has a DLC where you play as Justine, is more of a kind of "love" story with a new monster representing 3 people.
It was kind of decent, this game didn't need a DLC but it is cool that it has one!
It also has a short story called: Remember, which is a nice little extra that the game did not need...

Título: Sumérgete en el Abismo del Terror: Amnesia: The Dark Descent

Amnesia: The Dark Descent, creado por Frictional Games, es un pilar del género del survival horror que ha cautivado a jugadores de todo el mundo con su atmósfera intensa y su narrativa inmersiva. Mi experiencia con este juego ha sido una montaña rusa de emociones, y estoy encantado de compartir mis pensamientos sobre esta experiencia de juego inolvidable.

Lo que me ha gustado:

Atmósfera Angustiante: Desde el momento en que comienzas, Amnesia: The Dark Descent te sumerge en un mundo de oscuridad y misterio. Los efectos de sonido inquietantes y la iluminación tenue crean una atmósfera de tensión constante que te hace sentir constantemente vigilado.

Narrativa Profunda: La historia es el corazón de este juego. A medida que exploras el oscuro castillo y descubres los oscuros secretos de tu pasado, te ves envuelto en una trama intrigante que te atrapa y no te suelta hasta el final. Los detalles y las pistas están magistralmente tejidos en la trama, fomentando la curiosidad del jugador.

Diseño de Puzzles Creativos: Los rompecabezas en el juego son desafiantes pero lógicos. Requieren observación y reflexión, lo que añade una capa adicional de inmersión al juego. Resolver estos enigmas es una satisfacción que te impulsa a seguir adelante en la historia.

Inteligente Sistema de Miedo: Amnesia: The Dark Descent se destaca por su sistema de miedo. No se trata solo de enfrentarte a monstruos, sino de lidiar con tu propia cordura. La falta de luz y la exposición prolongada a los horrores del juego afectan tu salud mental, creando una experiencia de juego única y aterradora.

Lo que no me ha gustado:

En mi experiencia, Amnesia: The Dark Descent es un juego casi impecable. Sin embargo, algunos jugadores pueden encontrar el nivel de dificultad de los rompecabezas un poco alto, lo que puede ser frustrante para aquellos que prefieren una experiencia de juego más relajada.

Recomendación:

Recomendaría Amnesia: The Dark Descent sin reservas a cualquier persona que busque una experiencia de terror genuina y una narrativa inmersiva. Este juego va más allá de simplemente asustarte: te sumerge en un mundo de pesadillas del cual es difícil escapar.

Prestar atención a los detalles y seguir la historia a través de la perspectiva del creador puede ofrecer una comprensión más profunda y enriquecer tu experiencia.

En resumen, Amnesia: The Dark Descent es una obra maestra del género del survival horror. Si tienes el coraje y la curiosidad para adentrarte en lo desconocido, este juego te llevará en un viaje emocionante y aterrador que nunca olvidarás. ¡Buena suerte y que la luz te guíe a través de las sombras!

If you're thinking of playing this game I hope you've been able to avoid spoilers! They really soil the experience but that's kinda just how the horror genre works in general. Blindly jumping in is the best way to play. Turn down the lights, save the achievement hunting til your second playthrough (if you're into that kind of thing) and crank up the volume. I'm a big survival horror fan! I don't often enjoy horror games that omit combat as I find them too lacking in real substance as I just feel so limited. This game is one of those horror games, and the game play is as simple as can be. Minimal resource management, you have health items, tinder boxes to light a few light sources here and there, and oil to fuel your hand lantern. All other items you find will be key items for solving puzzles to progress. You'd think this means I wouldn't enjoy this game but I was pleasantly surprised!
The game's sanity mechanic requires you to avoid dark corners as being in the dark will decrease your sanity.
Low sanity causes your character to hear noises, hallucinate bugs in their vision, and even make them harder to control. Being in lit areas helps you avoid this BUT makes it easier for monsters to spot you. This creates a simple but effective risk reward system where you sacrifice sanity by hiding in dark corners to avoid monsters.
The puzzles are serviceable albeit a bit cryptic at times when requiring to combine items you wouldn't really think to combine. The monsters are bit uninspired design wise for me, they look kinda silly but the feeling of being chased was still tense and put a chill up my spine as I imagined the things chasing me! 
The story is told in a very fragmented manner and you will probably need to look up online to really grasp it all. But this feels intentional as the devs making it clear it is more about wandering and feeling the atmosphere which I think they succeed. The game captures the feeling of being a nightmare, dropping you into a moment that you feel scared and alone and you have no idea how you got there. 
My only note is the sanity mechanic could have more effects to feel more risky. Like when I was at low sanity, I really didn't feel like it was making the game harder or putting me in more danger.

[h1] Amnesia: The Dark Descent: A Masterclass in Horror Gaming [/h1]

When it comes to modern sequels to classics like Alone in the Dark, Amnesia: The Dark Descent by Frictional Games stands out as the true successor to the original terror-filled adventures. This first-person horror adventure, from the creators of the Penumbra trilogy, immerses players in a Lovecraftian nightmare, leaving them stranded alone in the dark depths of a haunted castle filled with lurking terrors. In many ways, Amnesia surpasses its legendary predecessor, eschewing cheesy action sequences for a relentless, spine-tingling experience.

You step into the shoes of Daniel, who wakes up in the ominous halls of Brennenburg Castle with a severe case of amnesia. The game initially evokes a Memento-like vibe as Daniel attempts to piece together his past through notes, diary entries, and sudden flashbacks. While the amnesia trope might be clichéd, Frictional Games weaves it into the narrative with remarkable finesse. The story unfolds in intriguing morsels scattered throughout the game, beckoning you into a chilling castle inhabited by a protagonist teetering on the brink of madness, hunted by enigmatic horrors. From the outset, you sense you're being inexorably drawn toward a revelation that promises anything but a happy ending. Yet, you can't help but yearn to uncover the truth.

The storytelling and overall structure are exceptionally executed. Amnesia is a true horror game where peril is immediate. Daniel, bereft of weapons or supernatural powers, faces relentless danger from the outset. Confrontation is not an option; you must evade the nightmarish entities lurking in the castle's shadows. Direct confrontation leads either to insanity or a gruesome demise. But hiding in the shadows is no refuge either, for Daniel is so deeply unhinged that darkness itself terrifies him. Thus, you face a grim choice: linger in the pools of light, risking encounters with eldritch horrors, or venture into the darkness, inviting a one-way ticket to the asylum. Resources like tinderboxes and lamp oil, which illuminate your path, are scarce, prompting you to scurry between the scarce islands of light in this abyss.

Amnesia orchestrates an atmosphere of constant unease. You'll find yourself darting through rooms, avoiding foes that may not even be there. The formidable adversaries are both rare and lethal, serving as occasional threats rather than relentless pursuers, preserving the game's focus on tension and dread over action-packed chases. The eerie castle rooms are masterfully designed, replete with decaying walls, rain-sodden holes in the ceiling, and solitary candles flickering in dimly lit cellars. The creeping sense of dread follows you like a shadow, enhancing the anticipation of impending horrors. The descent into madness is visualized through distorted colors, disorienting camera angles, and unsettling visual glitches. You're left perpetually uncertain about reality.

Sound design plays a pivotal role in amplifying the tension. Daniel's mutterings reflect his deteriorating sanity, rain pours outside, footsteps echo mysteriously, and sudden gusts of wind extinguish candles. Unexplained voices cry for help. The environment consistently conspires to unnerve you.

However, Amnesia primarily offers an eerie experience rather than a grueling challenge. Although it excels in crafting an unsettling atmosphere and dousing players in dread through the "fear of the dark" mechanic, most of its puzzles are fairly straightforward. These puzzles involve key hunting, object manipulation, evading perilous jumps, pulling levers, and more. You may seldom find yourself stumped, as long as you remain observant and can navigate the labyrinthine castle layout. The puzzles, while not particularly difficult, feel integral to the narrative rather than contrived obstacles. Solving them leaves you with a sense of accomplishment.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a haunting masterpiece in the horror gaming genre. Although its duration might be relatively short, around six hours of gameplay, the game's price tag of $20 as an online download compensates for its brevity. Regardless of its length, this is an experience that will etch itself into your memory—an uncanny, unsettling, and genuinely terrifying journey, especially when played in the dark with headphones on.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a psychological horror masterpiece that redefined the horror gaming genre when it was released in 2010 by Frictional Games. With its immersive storytelling, spine-tingling atmosphere, and innovative gameplay, it quickly became a benchmark for horror games. In this review, we'll delve into the chilling depths of this game to uncover what makes it a timeless classic in the world of gaming.

Storyline:
Amnesia: The Dark Descent plunges players into the shoes of Daniel, a man who awakens in a gloomy, foreboding castle with no memory of his past. As he explores the eerie corridors and chambers, he uncovers a sinister history involving dark rituals, unspeakable horrors, and his own complicity in a series of gruesome events. The game's narrative is delivered through haunting notes, diary entries, and disturbing encounters, creating an immersive and deeply unsettling experience.

Atmosphere and Immersion:
The game's greatest triumph is its ability to immerse players in its nightmarish world. The atmosphere is oppressive, with dimly lit hallways, creaking floors, and an omnipresent sense of dread. The sound design is exceptional, with haunting whispers, distant cries, and unsettling noises that keep you constantly on edge. The game's use of lighting and shadows adds to the sense of vulnerability, making you feel like you're truly in a place where every corner could conceal a lurking horror.

Gameplay and Puzzles:
Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a survival horror game with a unique twist—it emphasizes stealth and evasion over combat. You are unarmed and defenseless against the grotesque monstrosities that roam the castle, which intensifies the fear factor. Instead of battling enemies, you must hide from them, adding an extra layer of tension to the gameplay.

The puzzles in the game are cleverly designed, seamlessly integrated into the narrative, and often require players to think critically and creatively. They range from deciphering cryptic messages to manipulating the environment to progress, enhancing the sense of immersion and challenge.

Horror Elements:
The horror in Amnesia is psychological, relying on fear of the unknown, a sense of helplessness, and the dread of what might be lurking around the next corner. The game's monsters are grotesque and terrifying, and encountering them is genuinely panic-inducing. Your sanity is a tangible gameplay mechanic, as staying in darkness for too long or witnessing horrific events causes Daniel to descend into madness, blurring the line between reality and delusion.

Replayability:
While Amnesia: The Dark Descent's main story may take around 8-10 hours to complete, its replayability comes from the different choices players can make throughout the game and its numerous hidden secrets and Easter eggs. Additionally, the modding community has created a wealth of custom stories and content, extending the game's longevity.

Conclusion:
Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a genre-defining horror game that remains a masterpiece in the medium. Its commitment to psychological horror, outstanding storytelling, and unrelenting atmosphere create an experience that will haunt players long after they've turned off their computers. If you're a fan of horror games and haven't experienced this classic, prepare yourself for a descent into madness that you won't soon forget.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a truly terrifying video game experience but one that is also memorable and probably also nostalgic to some. For me this was my first playthrough and every counter, despite most of them being scripted monster encounters, did make me feel really terrified. Had my first "NOPE" moment in the Northern Prison after accidently turning the right corner instead of walking into the kitchen area.. 

The Choir was the most tense experience ever, I had to follow a walkthrough since I was just too scared to walk around the dim hallway all on my own and at late evening at that. The sound of Brute growling in headphones and my imagination was already scary enough..

The Gatherers (aka servant grunts) are pretty stupid and they don't give too much effort to chase you, especially if you are being careful enough to hide behind a corner, any corner, and put away your lantern for a while. My best advice whether you are facing a Grunt or a Brute would be to wait for their hunting music to slowly go away because that would signal that the coast is clear and you can step forward.

The game is difficult but just like Visage, it's not "unfair" if you get killed by a monster numerous times they wiill spawn less. If you die it is possible for you to spawn close to the exit, that's what happened to me in the Storage room. I happened to respawn at the exact location when I died and only one grunts was chasing me for 5 seconds, I could almost literally see both the Grunt and the exit door right in front of me lol. Some players have trolled the monsters and it is possible to glitch them to get stuck on one place or make them fall down into an endless pit to get rid off them if you really have high skill, I don't but I have seen other people do it on YouTube

As for the story, well no spoilers but the game is not for the faint of heart. There is a lot of gore, both audible and visual. You will be exposed to torture devices, disturbing noises and a whole lot of corpses, blood and dismembered body parts. If you are sensitive to all that kind of stuff I would suggest maybe not play this game.. but if that is no issue for you by all means, play it. It's a really good game and getting revenge on Alexander is actually both quite funny and satisfying. 

General advice for beginners, you only have a very limited amount of oil in your lantern as well as tinderboxes so you'd need to preserve those items and use them sparingly. Don't stand around in the darkness for too long and move along quickly to avoid sanity drain. If you feel too scared just allow yourself to be killed by the enemy, not sure how it is like in the Choir but they generally spawn less when you get killed multiple times by them. Enemies can see you in the light so it is best to use every light source you have with extreme caution. 

Be patient with yourself and the game, take regular breaks from the game if being chased has caused you a big amount of stress, that is okay. The game auto-saves but you can also choose to save manually and just press continue to resume your adventure from where you left off during your last save. There are around 4-5 safe hubs where there are no enemy encounters so there are breaks in-between to allow you to catch some breath before putting you through another terrifying experience. The game has 4 endings and yeah, I think this is enough I can say right now to keep it spoilerfree

Good luck if you choose to play the game and remember, patience is the key to making progress!

143640245.review:
Having completed Amnesia: The Bunker, I decided to revisit my favourite horror game, Amnesia: The Dark Descent. No matter how many times I return to Brennenburg Castle, I am always genuinely delighted by such a turn of events.

The player has the opportunity to be part of the story of a young archaeologist by the name of Daniel. During an excavation, his team discovered a mysterious artefact in the shape of an orb. Suddenly, the site collapsed and Daniel found himself buried alive under the rubble. In his delirium, he started to see strange visions, and when he regained his senses, he noticed that the sphere had been split and its pieces had not fit together. Daniel miraculously managed to escape, only to find that something else appeared in his life and threatened to destroy him. The protagonist was then plagued by bad dreams and haunted by eerie images. His mind began to deteriorate, and numerous friends and doctors who tried to help him eventually perished under mysterious circumstances. He realised that it was the strange orb that was responsible, but he had no idea how to get rid of the curse that was haunting him. Desperate to find answers to his questions, Daniel sent letters to various scientific societies and to the friends of his professor acquaintance. Unfortunately, he was unsuccessful, and only after some time did he receive a reply from a certain Alexander, who said something along the lines of "I know everything, come to me". Upon further investigation, Daniel found out that this Alexander was of noble blood and was a resident of his own castle, Brennenburg, in Prussia. With no other options open to him, the protagonist immediately set off for the damp and foggy country to meet his new and mysterious patron.

This game once won me over with its narrative style. We are thrown into the thick of things without much preamble: we are in a huge castle and remember nothing, it is raining outside the window and a cold wind blows through the ornate corridors. Our uncertain footsteps echo around the room and we feel completely alone. Inevitably, Daniel will come into contact with the inhabitants. Their motives are not entirely benevolent.

The story is told in flashbacks. Despite this jerky form of narration, the plot is perceived as a whole, and at the end we have a complete assembled picture. Furthermore, in Amnesia, I experienced for the first time the mechanics of a panic attack in the protagonist, when he is in the dark for a long time and needs to be near a light source for a while to reclaim his sanity. As the light would have made us easy prey for the so-called Gatherers, it was a lot of tension for me every time I had to hide in the dark, but it was fun to stare at candles to regain my sanity.

Despite the game's clever combination of light and dark sections and unusual mechanics, the intelligence of the enemies here is not particularly sophisticated, and they quickly lose sight of the player. The game has a large number of scripted chases, so one will not be able to avoid monster encounters entirely. The music that accompanies the chases, on the other hand, will have you cowering in your chair in fear.

The game certainly has a nice dark level design and a marvellous ambience. The dimmed lights and monsters prowling around in the dark create an outstanding atmosphere that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Even though I have completed Amnesia several times, I still fall for this trick every time.

It is also worth mentioning that there is a hard mode in which autosaves are completely disabled, monsters become more aggressive and alert, and manual saves cost 4 tinderboxes. In the regular game, these were used to light candles to restore one's mental health and to mark a path for one to follow in the dark. Besides that, one can memorise the location of all the tinderboxes, unlike the hard mode, where their appearance is random and each tinderbox is greeted with enthusiastic applause. Hard mode presents a serious and demanding challenge to the player, although there are a few differences from normal mode.

No matter how many times I have returned to Amnesia, I have always enjoyed the game's ability to tickle the nerves. The 'Choir - Main Hall' location constantly stresses me with its layout and the soundtrack playing in the background, so it has become my habit to slowly creep along the walls, literally feeling them with my backside and listening for every sound. It is an incredible place with an extremely eerie atmosphere and a powerful ambience!

The bottom line is as follows: Amnesia TDD is truly a masterpiece and one of the best survival horrors of all time!

142482107.review:
One of the best games in horror. I've played through it twice, once when I wasn't experienced in horror games, and much later when I was. One particularly great part of this game is that it doesn't just try and surprise you into fear, it actively makes you engage with the horror in ways that feel totally hopeless. For example, there'll be many times where you're alerted to a monster in a location, whether they're behind a door or in the water or something, and you'll need to go where they are to progress. You're not just running away from monsters here, you're also constantly battling with yourself, trying to avoid them as much as possible and stay sane while knowing you'll have to invade their environments to go forward. The mechanics all work together really well to make this an unsettling experience. Ironically, it actually feels pretty fair, not trying to scare you or make you feel hopeless with cheap tricks, but crafting the environment in a way that makes those feelings slowly build with you.

A good part too, is that the game knows when to let you take a breather. It makes sure to reward you with sequences that feel safe after a long time spent in danger, like the world itself is taking a breather alongside you. In that way, it also makes it harder to get used to the horror scenarios, so you really never feel like you properly adapt, which is a very good thing in a game trying to inspire fear. The atmosphere, and most of the puzzles/scenarios are just fantastic. Great game, whether this is your first horror game or your 15th.

It's important for me to preface this review with the following;
I do not play a lot of horror games. I had not [b]played[/b], let alone [b]finished[/b], many horror games before this. Mostly, this comes down to me being a very naturally anxious person who is stupidly easy to scare, thus I struggle to stomach them, so until this the only horror games I had completed were [i]'Omori'[/i], [i]'i live under your house'[/i], [i]'System Shock 2'[/i] and a few [i]'Five Nights at Freddy's'[/i] games. With this qualifier presented, I can say with confidence that Frictional Game's [i]'Amnesia: The Dark Descent'[/i] is easily the scariest game I've ever encountered, and in spite of some tiny flaws elicited such a strong emotional reaction from me that it would be remiss for me to not consider it among the medium's finest. 

At first, the prospect of a 'sanity' metre—an idea found immeditley quaint for lovecraftian games soon after the admittedly novel antics of [i]'Eternal Darkness'[/i] found their way dancing atop the GameCube—and the titular trope making pose as the story hook had me worrying a potential glaze over was inbound, a worry quickly sedated by a realisation I had early in the game that even with all the red pus germinating in the walls, [i]'The Dark Descent'[/i] had been able to demonstrate a shocking level of restraint in the way it chose to unnerve me thus far. While worry would not be truly cured until later, Frictional's dedication to pacing had me intrigued enough to fully immerse myself in both the excellent atmosphere and writing. The technical quality of the writing found in the notes is quite the admirable one, since the game would have done perfectly fine narratively without it, hooking players into what is presently the story of a man going nuts in the dark trying to set his bad deeds right. The added digresional textures of colonial guilt and characterisation were certainly elevatory when they could easily have been detrimental, leaving me satisifed with their inclusion. 

[i]'Amnesia'[/i] is also quite effectivley dreary, with fantastic lighting and crestfallen texture work adorning it's traumatisied and despotic halls. Structures held a balance between intimidation and the alien tipping on both ends against the players comfort. Rooms can be tight and dark, spotted with brief drips of light which can become a pool only at the daring cost of the player's resources, or they can be looming, oversized and intimidating. This atmosphere of oppresion is essential to a horror experience, and well adjusted here. 

The alleviation of my minor irritation at the value of a 'sanity' mechanic came with my introduction to the monsters of Brennenburg. Now, this doesn't happen until a few hours in due to the commitment to narrative pacing present in [i]'The Dark Descent'[/i] but they add a [b]lot[/b] to the game. First, they give the "sanity" mechanic a purpose beyond the superficial; as maxing out the metre renders the game unplayable, the sheer act of looking at the monsters will raise the gameplay into a horrid state, meaning the player is forced to keep their eyes off them! This is genius because it allows the player's imagination to do a lot of work for Frictional, having me wholeheartedly afraid of them from entry to exit. While the bugs-crawling-across-the-monitor illusion and other more superfluous consequences of loosing 'sanity' are silly, this contextualisation of the mechanic with a core player struggle was too complimentary to the rest of the game for me to dislike the feature. Wish they'd call it 'stress' or something though because 'sanity' still sounds mega silly. 

Some puzzles are a little dense, but all are ultimately satisfying, there's even some instances of emergent gameplay, which is always welcome! Really I have nothing to complain about here. Frictional have delivered a subperb, clever, and hauntingly beautiful horror masterpiece here which still holds up well over a decade later! This, my friends—let us waggle our judging fingers at Bloober team as they piss all over team silent's legacy—is the key to a memorable and powerful horror experience, subtlety and considered, oppresive mechanics! Nothing short of excellent.

[h1]”Don't forget, some things mustn't be forgotten. The shadow hunting me... I must hurry. My name is Daniel, I live in London at... at... Mayfair. What have I done? This is crazy. Don't forget, don't forget! I must stop him! Focus! My name is... is... I am Daniel.”[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Amnesia: The Dark Descent is an atmospheric survival horror experience where Daniel, the character you play, is defenceless against the horrors he will face as he descends into the darkness of the castle.
But did Amnesia have enough oil in the lantern to stave off insanity, or was it lost to the abyss?

[table]
[tr]
    [th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
    [th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
    [td]🟩 An excellent horror atmosphere combined with how defenceless you are against enemies will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

🟩 Interesting world design coaxes you to explore resources and items and forces you to react quickly to some stressful situations that arise.

🟩 The physics allows for some fascinating puzzle mechanics.

🟩 Amnesia won't win any beauty awards as the dated graphics offer very little visually astounding, but this assists the atmosphere significantly. The grim castle architecture and blood-smeared walls definitely help define the experience from a visual standpoint. The audio is much the same, outdated yet enjoyable.[/td]
    [td]🟥 The enemy AI is pretty foolish. The monsters hunting you rely on surprise appearances and their speed to catch you.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The game casts you into the role of Daniel, a Londoner who awakens in the dark halls of the Prussian Brennenburg Castle. With little to no memory of himself or his past, all that he remembers is his name and that something sinister is hunting him.

Daniel sets off on his journey, dazed and confused, lost in the maze-like hallways of Brennenburg, until he comes across a note that he had apparently left for himself. The message details that he had forced himself to forget his past to preserve his innocence by utilising an amnesia potion. The letter goes on to urge Daniel to descend the castle in search of his host, a man named Alexander and to murder him and with one final warning that a "living nightmare" is chasing him and that he must find a way to escape because there are no means of fighting it.

Armed with this knowledge and a trusty lantern he was able to scrounge for, he sets off towards the depths of the dark, neglected castle, with horrors and nightmares on his heels.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2999878783

Amnesia: The Dark Descent does an exceptional job of immersing you in this story of deception, betrayal and discovery as Daniel descends into his own living nightmare. The plot is heavily reliant on you searching for and reading the notes scattered across the world, there is limited narrative to the game, and if you don't seek these out, you will be left wondering what is actually happening.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]The darkness, closing in.[/h3]
🟩 As you will quickly begin to understand as you progress through the story, light is your closest ally and worst enemy. It will protect you from losing your sanity as you wander the castle and witness the supernatural horrors that lurk within it, but you will also need to embrace the darkness to stay out of their sight. Managing this balance is entirely up to you.

🟩 Sanity is a very tangible resource in this game. It will fall as you witness supernatural events or if you spend too long looking at the horrors that roam the halls. The best way to manage this state is by sticking to the light. You can light candles and torches by utilising tinderboxes you can find scattered across the world or your lantern that requires oil to activate. Losing too much sanity causes your vision to blur and your senses to lose focus, and if left to fall totally will cause Daniel to collapse.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2999878703

🟥 The enemies are few and far between and mostly avoidable. They aren't very clever and follow some semblance of a scripted path. The best solution quite often is sitting in a dark corner for a few moments out of sight, and they'll usually get bored and walk away.

[h3]A chance to redeem yourself.[/h3]
🟩 When you're not running, hiding and avoiding the nightmares, you will likely find yourself completing puzzles. There are dozens of puzzles to solve across the castle grounds, ranging in intricacy from simple to sophisticated.

🟩 Many of them are actually remarkably inventive and amusing, especially the deceptively simple ones.

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
As up above, Amnesia isn't going to blow you away with flashy graphics or astounding visuals. It does provide a gritty, atmospheric world that does immerse you in this living nightmare. Despite its dated graphics and design choices, the game still managed to attain a stifled gasp at some of the more stressful panic moments.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2999878456

The audio is actually far more impressive though it's also dated. It provides a fantastic overall ambience to the world, where every footfall raises your tension, and the creak of every door you wish would be silent rings loudly through the halls.

[h1]PC Performance and Specifications[/h1]
Amnesia is an old game, and it's safe to assume most anyone can run it with a somewhat recent computer.

There were no graphical issues to report.

[h1]Final Thoughts - Very Good[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a well-recognised survival horror experience within the genre. It paved the way for a lot of the mechanics we know in modern games of its ilk, and I believe it deserves a lot of praise for those commendable efforts. Despite its age, it still manages to deliver an astounding horror experience and sets a benchmark for atmosphere and world design. Definitely recommend this title to anyone who is a fan of the genre.

If we were in a parallel universe, where my face wasn’t best suited for radio and my voice tailor-made to be in a silent film, I’d probably scratch my critique-disseminating itch by running some kind of YouTube channel. And on that channel, [i]Amnesia: The Dark Descent[/i] would be my nemesis game. I’d hold my head in my hands, loudly sigh, look straight into the camera and go: “I really didn’t want to have to do this (audible shrug), but here we are!”. Boom—cut to the logo, play the theme music.

Well, here we are indeed, and although I didn’t [b]have[/b] to do this, I wish I had! Instead, I’m going off my own wants and needs, unremarkably adding my own voice to the tens of thousands—maybe even hundreds—that have been heard since this insanely influential game came out over a decade ago.

[i]The Dark Descent[/i] has been a personal demon for a while now. For years, I considered it the title that made everyone forget what exactly it was that made horror games such a great and unique experience, pulling them away from tense battles of wit towards drama-driven, cinematic haunted house rides. Turns out, the monster under the bed wasn’t as bad as I initially thought.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2997611128

[h3]The Heart of the Matter[/h3]

There’s a peculiar sense of scale and isolation to the freshly industrialised world, when steam machinery was your best bet for long-distance travel. It’s that specific point in our history that [i]The Dark Descent[/i] takes place at—Britain is at the height of its power, and the ever-growing colonial tendencies of the Western European powers are ramping up to the Scramble for Africa. With real-world technological advances came new plot devices to get the curious adventurer far away from the comfort of his home (similar to how the advent of the e-mail was a godsend to any future immersive sim developers), and right into the mysteries that lie in wait across the Mediterranean and over the Alps in these new lands now ripe for the picking.

Industrialization and colonialism aren’t quite what [i]The Dark Descent[/i] is about, but it’s a story that is heavily informed by the period it’s set in, as Daniel, a British archaeologist, finds himself pursued by a destructive, supernatural force after uncovering a strange artefact during an expedition in Algiers. With promises of refuge, he seeks the aid of one Alexander of Brennenburg, an eccentric Prussian nobleman and inventor.

Thus, Brennenburg Castle is where you’ll be exploring, as unfolding events require Daniel to brave its darkest depths; a descent in many ways, as he comes face to face with the terrible truths that await him and as the welcoming, warm exterior of the castle slowly makes way for the gargantuan mechanisms and surreal architecture that lie further in.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2997590832

Strong art direction and an engaging storyline drive things forward in [i]The Dark Descent[/i]. As is survival horror tradition, uncovering what went down and how it went down won’t exactly be straightforward, but will require additional effort to be uncovered. Fear is the barrier you’ll need to overcome for all your goals around these parts, and I wouldn’t have it any other way.

Surprise, surprise—Daniel is an amnesiac, meaning he doesn’t immediately remember much of anything, other than his name. Thankfully, writing journals and taking notes is everyone’s favourite pastime in survival horror; there’s nothing wrong with that, and the ones in [i]The Dark Descent[/i] are written with, and I’ll be blunt, some damn inspired prose. What actually got me, though, were the loading screen tips having a subtle narrative impact of their own, by mimicking fragments of Daniel’s memory clicking back in place whenever a new area needs to be loaded in.

[h3] Wait, Survival Horror?[/h3]

That is what I said—and so we are roped into the old action vs psychological vs survival horror debate.

I'll admit it, I’m a bit dismissive when it comes to all the games that [i]Amnesia[/i] inspired—just look above—but that's all because I'm a bit peeved that all my favourites started leaning into their action elements more and more around that same time, and psychological horror all but took over the stage. In reality, judging an entire subgenre on its worst examples, which all took the wrong lessons from this game, would be the same as stereotyping survival horror as horror-themed action schlock. Okay, before you say it, I agree that it is an accurate summation of [i]Resident Evil[/i], but it’s so much more than that—just like psychological horror can be more than hiding in lockers or running around until something screams in your face. 

I’ll always get my jimmies rustled more by careful ammo conservation or the rationing of healing items in the heat of the moment, but I don’t think survival horror is inherently scarier or, hell, even superior when compared to its counterparts. It just works better for [b]me[/b], and this game has, for a long time, been the presumed culprit of why I've been deprived of it for years.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2997601113

I say this because my choice to classify [i]The Dark Descent[/i] as survival horror doesn’t come from a place of elitism, but its underlying mechanics. That's the point of survival horror—providing the player choice when faced with their fears. [i]The Dark Descent[/i] makes the choice of not fighting back for you, but tries to offer other choices as much as it can to compensate. 

Take the whole physics-based puzzle system, or the way hiding and opening doors works. There are no one-button presses or quick time events—it’s all done by holding and dragging the mouse. Every item not glued to the floor can be moved, and each one you move to where it needs to be, every inch you open a door to continue onwards—a victory. Even if it isn't taken as far as I'd have liked it to, It makes your presence in the world, and the imminent danger you’re in, that much palpable.

The blur-inducing, screen-warping post-processing effects and abundant dark areas aren’t just cheap visuals or lazy scare tactics, but gameplay elements; spend enough time near enemies or in darkness and Daniel's sanity will drop, causing him to hear or see things that might not be there. Still, inventory management is a crucial aspect of survival, you’re just managing your lantern’s oil and your supply of tinderboxes, used to light up torches and candles, instead of ammo.

Regardless, it’s not a game that looks to punish failure with loss of progress. Death will leave you more or less where you left off, with the caveat that any spent resources up until that point remain spent. It’s clear that overcoming your fear is the real challenge here, perhaps paradoxically now that your inability to do so earlier has left you in a worse place. Now, what does that remind me of…

[h3]Verdict[/h3]

For all the time it took me to come to [i]The Dark Descent[/i] and the rationale that kept me from it, I can’t help but feel a little bit of remorse. I can’t possibly fault it for a lot of the games that came after it learning all the wrong lessons, can I? It’s not like I found anything during my playthrough that would warrant calling it a poor teacher.

As a friend put it, it’s old and dated, not even breaking into his top ten, with a stifled gasp being the best it deserves. I concur, and even if it doesn’t deliver in spectacular fashion on everything I look for first and foremost in a survival horror experience, the takeaways I came out with left me with a lot more respect than I had for it in all those years prior.

140797213.review:
[h1] Amnesia: The Dark Descent - 2023 review [/h1]

The first entry in the Amnesia franchise still shines to this day. Although it has gotten somewhat old, Amnesia: The Dark Descent brings core horrific immersion that is unmatched by most horror games nowadays.

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*] The sound design is definitely polished. By the shear soundtrack and audio mix, you'll feel trapped in a nightmare that will definitely chill you to the bone.
[*] The level design matches the progression perfectly, making key areas the perfect length to explore before moving on to the next without getting bored. All of the areas are incredible and threatening in their own way.
[*] Although it can be quite complex to understand the whole thing, the story is amazing. This game is hands down a gem for horror storytelling, with good plot twists and extension of the lore through lots of notes (which are surprisingly worth reading compared to the majority of games).
[*] The system requirements for this game are extremely low, pretty much anyone can run it decently. [/list]

[b] Neutrals [/b]
[list]
[*] Both the graphics and the art style are decent, nothing too crazy, they hold up to this day. However, I've heard this game has mods that can make it look a lot better, I haven't looked into it unfortunately.
[*] The gameplay is also decent at best. It's a mix of a formula loved by fans even today (such as finding tinderboxes to light the place, finding fuel to light your lamp...) but I found it to be a tad annoying sometimes. Resources aren't consistent between areas, thus making it a pain to learn how to manage them. Some people will find this better for immersion, some will find it annoying, that's why it's in the [i] Neutrals [/i] category.
[*] The game's length is good. It took me around 8 hours to finish it completely. I haven't played the DLC yet (Amnesia: Justine), but I'll get there eventually.
[*] Performances are great, but it feels like the game isn't optimised enough to hit over 100 fps even on a high-end PC for my part. I was somewhat disappointed. [/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*] If you're a completionist looking to 100% this game without a guide, it'll be a nightmare for you. Reading all the documents is enough of a pain, but it also requires you to find all the tinderboxes in the entire game. 
[*] The physics are wonky and outdated. Some will say it brings a charm to the game. I've actually encountered some bugs because of it that broke my immersion. This is an expected negative aspect considering the game's age, but I prefer pointing it out.
[*] The horror aspects don't hit like they used to. Unfortunately, although the atmosphere is phenomenal, the monsters are goofy for today's standards, and I ended up laughing more than panicking on many occasions. Some scary elements may fall flat to most recent horror games, like Outlast for example. [/list]

[b] TL;DR [/b]
A classic and great horror game that (kind of) holds up to today's standards in many ways. The storytelling is amazing, the progression is great and it's fun to explore the depths of the Brennenburg Castle. The atmosphere is also really immersive. Most horror elements don't scare like they use to, unfortunately, and the physics are outdated. Those are both expected from a 13 year old game, but they definitely break the immersion on some occasion. If you're a completionist, you will suffer trying to finish this game without watching a guide. Overall, definitely worth playing if you're into horror games and good storytelling and don't mind this game's age.

[b] Rating: 7/10 [/b]

140680986.review: The Dark Descent is a classic; a little game by an indie studio that had a cultural impact of a meteor. It has launched Youtube careers, an entire subgenre, and a number of copycat games - among them lots of drivel, but also some truly inspired works of art. Does it feel like a worthy precursor to modern interactive horror? Honestly, it feels like we haven't progressed that far from that initial achievement; Frictional Games' design feels timeless. It's mostly smoke and mirrors, but it cheats you in to such a powerful feeling of wonder and terror that it's hard to compare with anything else. I actually haven't finished it back in 2010 because the frights were nigh unbearable, but having played (and tremendously enjoyed) The Bunker earlier this month, I knew I had to give it another try. I enjoyed it A LOT, and I honestly don't think I've played anything like it. It's an adventure puzzle game at heart, the horror-oriented mechanics are not particularly developed, but the sound design does the work and the atmosphere is strong all the way through. The only complaint I could have is the ending(s) - a little underwhelming.

140158418.review:
At this point in 2023, I'd recommend people play this game, for the same reason I'd recommend you play classic Resident Evil, or Clock Tower, or even the first Alone in the Dark. Are these games "good?" No idea, but they find unique and inventive ways to scare you, and I suppose that's the most important part of a horror game. 

I can't speak to what horror indie games were before this, other than the fact that I've played Penumbra, and this is a huge leap forward from that game. 

That being said, indie horror has come quite a ways since Amnesia- just look at Frictional's own Soma for evidence of that. Then you have crazy stuff like Darkwood and the Consuming Shadow; the latter game created by a dev who has gone on record as being inspired by Amnesia. 

I do think it's a shame that Frictional feels the need to slap the Amnesia name on most of the games they've made since, but the original is definitely worth a bit of your time.

139703102.review:
Ah, Amnesia. A horror game that changed its genres landscape and cemented horror as one of the most popular genres of game. A game that (greatly) helped  Frictional Games and jump started the careers of world famous You-tubers such as Pewdiepie, Markiplier, CinnamonToastKen, etc.  A game that changed the way horror games are developed, indie or triple A, even to this day (for better or worse depending who you ask). But was it even any good in the first place? Does it hold up? What makes this game special? And why am I reviewing this game in 2023.

Well, with the release of Amnesia Bunker yesterday (and seeing Amnesia Dark Descent at only $3 due to a steam sale), I decided if it would be a perfect time to start playing Amnesia and find the answers to these questions above. 

First of all, let's start with the positives. Spoiler alert, the positives far outweigh any negatives and answers the first two questions I started this review with with an astounding YES! Controlling your character is serviceable and smooth; no tank-like or clunky controls (Though turn that mouse sensitivity up in the settings since it's set at 1 for some reason). The physics engine really gives the gameplay some nice flavor and makes you feel a sense of freedom in such a creepy, linear, and confined space. Oh, and I forgot to mention about how the atmosphere: it's quite awesome. The sound design, music, lighting, set pieces, etc. compliment the game quite a bit. This game is essentially a masterclass in sound design and music, both impressing you and making you shit your pants at the same time. You have to make decisions based on sound cues and music that alerts and gives information about the monsters. Gives you a sense of dread and fear, which makes the game even scarier. The lighting and set pieces/environments really goes well with the music and sounds and nothing feels out of place. There are many dark spaces with occasional places of light or light sources that you can light up. It makes you feel that the monster could be lurking in any corner, just waiting for you to turn the wrong direction to snatch you up while it's unseen. It also makes you think before you use your lantern or use light sources since there is a limited amount of "fuel" (especially in hard mode).
I've been yapping about the atmosphere, but what about more of the gameplay? How do you defend yourself? 
Its a first person survival horror game, and to answer the last question, the only way to defend yourself is to run and hide. This isn't Resident Evil where, even with limited ammo, you could and had to kill your enemies. This is Amnesia. You are playing as someone who is utterly defenseless and that adds to the atmosphere of this game. With the physics engine you could throw stuff at the monster, but that doesn't do much and is just a waste of time. Anyways, you also have a inventory system where you track your health, sanity, and fuel for your lantern. There are also certain objects that you need to collect and/or combine together to advance in the game. And with these objects you collect you solve puzzles, and there are quite a few, but not too much where the horror and gameplay is ruined (I'm talking to you Scorn) .
Lastly for the positives, I think the voice acting is well done and I feel is not talked about a lot I think. They fit the character very well and helps keep the story tight. There's no bad voice actors in my opinion, and thank God they didn't pull a Bethesda by using the same voice actor for many roles. But yet again, there are not as many characters in Amnesia, but you get the point. And for the story, it's very well done and makes you want to beat the game just for that, because it's very interesting and reveals itself over tine since your main character took Amnesia (duh vault417dan, we could've guessed). But I will not reveal anything specific, since that would be spoilers, and this game should be played.
There is also now workshop support, with makes it easier to access custom story, a gamemode that let' s you play fan made levels/mods which were created in the Amnesia engine. I respect Frictional Games for giving the fans this ability. It's a nice cherry on top to play when you're done with the main story even.

One part that I felt was neither a positive or negative was the graphics. They're serviceable, and while they've aged and weren't even peak graphics at the time, I don't mind. 

Now for the negatives. The monsters' can be idiots. Due to their flawed AI, you only need to hide behind an object or go above they're vision level and you won't have to worry about them. It's quite disappointing that the monsters that you were initially so scared of in the beginning get less scary over time, especially when you realize this. Also, speaking of the disappointing monsters, the first/grunt monsters look silly and derpy. Especially with how slow they are, it makes you point and laugh rather than tremble with fear. And there's one monster that had so much potential to be like the next killer Croc in Arkham Asylum,  but YOU CAN'T EVEN SEE IT! 
Some puzzles are just a little to long and dragged out as well. More of a minor complaint, but it can make the puzzles a little tedious.
And my last (but not least) negatives are the endings. They are so underwhelming and disappointing that it can be jarring. With so much build up and epic gaming, you wouldn't expect this trash at the end of the yellow brick road. It won't make you delete the game or prevent you from replaying for completion, but it just makes you go "What the hell is this?!".

Now for the conclusion, since this review has gone long enough. This game is so good and my favorite horror game. Even with a few issues, the game is still great and extremely replayable. It still holds up in 2023.

So what are you waiting for? PLAY THE GAME! As of now, it's only $3 and is a steal.
