Still as great a horror game as when it first came out! Though the graphics have aged a little bit, it still more than good enough to play. (And for anyone else, there is an HD mod out there that's apparently really good - though I felt no need for it, personally.)

I also really enjoy the story, and the ambience is fantastic. Voice acting is also top notch, IMO. If you haven't played this classic yet, then get to it!

The game also includes an official expansion/DLC called "Justine", which is a short story that can be played through in 15-20 minutes once you've learned it. It has more emphasis on puzzle solving, but you're definitely not safe in this side little story! It was good fun, and the story added a little bit to the overall world of Amnesia.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent also includes options for playing fan made stories, and there are a bunch of them out there - many really good, too!

The second sequel(not counting A Machine For Pigs) is being released very soon, so make sure you're ready by playing through this and Amnesia: Rebirth!

100% in roughly 20 hours. (Guide highly recommended for collectables and hard mode achievements.)

If you don't like opening doors with your face that completely obscures your field-of-view for presumably impending jump scares, this game isn't for you.

It's an immensely well-reviewed game if you don't mind somewhat gimmicky horror (and I mean mechanical gimmicks based on map changes, musical cues to provide non-verbal information, and areas free of monster spawns).

I have tried repeatedly and just end up closing it because of the beginning sequence, it doesn't sell me on continuing the experience like Prey (2017) did - which when it tricked you into jumpscares did so masterfully in purely optional ways ensnaring those inclined to explore a hostile environment (and there were plenty of clues indicating what theoretically could happen that made all it fall into place in a brilliant way).

Trying to start this game is like "ah I see random strangely indoor wind is blowing open doors purely to startle me", that's not fun - it reminds of me some of the particularly clunky/bad Resident Evil ports on the Wii U.

You can enjoy atmospheric horror and survival horror and still hate this game, or you can hate horror in general and still enjoy this game, your mileage may vary and "closed down the game within the first hour" is all too common; it makes it impossible to recommend to anyone.

I guess if you enjoy videos of people playing it that you could give it a try though.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent, developed by Frictional Games, is a spine-chilling masterpiece that redefines the horror genre. Released in 2010, it remains a landmark title that continues to terrify and captivate players with its atmospheric setting, innovative mechanics, and psychological scares.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Daniel, a man who awakens in a dark and foreboding castle with no memory of his past, Amnesia: The Dark Descent plunges you into a world of constant dread and suspense. The game's greatest strength lies in its ability to build an oppressive atmosphere, using sound design, lighting, and environmental details to create an eerie and unsettling experience. Every creaking floorboard, distant whisper, and flickering candle adds to the sense of impending doom, keeping you on edge throughout your journey.

The gameplay mechanics of Amnesia: The Dark Descent are centered around survival and stealth, emphasizing the vulnerability of the player character. Daniel is not a seasoned warrior; instead, he must rely on his wits and limited resources to navigate the treacherous castle and avoid the terrifying inhabitants that lurk in the shadows. The game introduces the concept of sanity, which deteriorates as Daniel encounters frightening events, forcing players to manage their mental state while facing unimaginable horrors. The unique "sanity meter" adds an extra layer of tension and immersion, as hallucinations and distorted perceptions become increasingly prevalent.

The puzzles in Amnesia: The Dark Descent are cleverly designed, requiring both logical thinking and a keen eye for details. They seamlessly integrate into the narrative, enhancing the sense of mystery and discovery. The game strikes a delicate balance between challenging the player and ensuring progression feels rewarding. The absence of combat mechanics further amplifies the feeling of vulnerability, making every encounter with the castle's inhabitants a terrifying ordeal that prompts strategic evasion and stealth.

Graphically, Amnesia: The Dark Descent may show its age, but its visual design still manages to create a hauntingly beautiful and grotesque world. The dimly lit corridors, decaying architecture, and macabre imagery contribute to a sense of dread and unease. Combined with the exceptional sound design, which employs a combination of eerie ambient noises and spine-chilling music, the game creates an immersive experience that will leave you sleepless.

One aspect that sets Amnesia apart is its captivating storyline. Through fragmented memories, notes, and letters, the game slowly unravels the dark secrets of the castle and Daniel's past. The narrative is compelling, filled with psychological twists and revelations that keep you engaged until the very end. It's a testament to the game's writing and storytelling that it successfully merges atmospheric horror with a thought-provoking plot.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent is not without its flaws, but they are minor in comparison to its overall excellence. Some players may find certain sections overly challenging or frustrating, and the lack of combat can be polarizing for those who prefer more action-oriented horror experiences. However, these elements are intentional choices that contribute to the game's unique identity.

In conclusion, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a landmark horror game that will leave a lasting impact on anyone brave enough to venture into its dark depths. With its immersive atmosphere, innovative gameplay mechanics, and captivating storytelling, it remains a testament to the power of psychological horror in gaming. If you have a taste for fear and enjoy being pushed to the limits of your sanity, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is an unforgettable experience that will haunt your dreams long after you've turned off the lights.

132344295.review:
I feel like more people should play/replay this today. I always hear people using TDD as a staple to compare other horror games to; as if it's a flawless masterpiece and the quality standard by which we should judge all other games in the genre. I wish they would take the time to remind themselves how the game actually feels to play now that it's over a decade old.

A:TDD is good. It's got tight controls, well put together ambience and atmosphere, stunning audio design, interesting and well delivered story, and a memorably identity of it's own in a genre quite over-saturated with low quality indie titles. The only real problem with it is, well, it's not particularly scary anymore. To the game's credit, this is almost entirely due to the gradual desensitisation of audiences to it's design elements, rather than any problems in the design itself.

Basically TDD was the game that created a lot of the moulds horror games have been using for the past decade, and as a result, what was once a fresh and unique experience has retroactively become just another by-the-numbers chasey hidey puzzle solving horror game. You have to give Frictional credit for creating, or at the very least popularising this style of horror game, but that credit won't help the game be scary again. It's a bittersweet irony that the game's immense success as a fresh new bone-chilling horror experience destined to revitalise it's genre is the very thing that's led to it being so predictable and sort of silly for modern horror audiences.

I still think it's great, of course. If you're not someone who plays horror games regularly and therefore aren't so versed in the usual genre clichés, maybe it'll still hold up for you in the spook department. For me though, I play horror games semi-regularly, and the only real sustainable factor in TDD nowadays is the story, which is worth it on it's own for sure, but the horror elements are too formulaic by 2023+ standards for it to fray any nerves.

As with any genre-defining game, you have to try to look at it from the perspective of it's time. Over the past 12+ years there have been thousands of games taking direct inspiration from it's influence. Impressive as it's legacy is, it has the inevitable consequence of wearing the unique elements of the original down as time goes on, and the end result is that TDD sadly feels quite generic when looked at from a modern perspective. I do wish more people made a habit of regularly replaying games like this, because it's hard to move in the horror sphere without seeing comparisons to older titles that, while effective horror experiences at the time, have since lost most, if not all of their edge with the eventual maturation of audiences.

It's a good game, marred by it's own influenced successors and their wider effects on the genre and it's audiences. Still worth playing because it's a piece of horror history, just don't be surprised if you end up having spontaneous shovel duels with the monsters for fun when you're meant to be running away.

130555512.review:
[THE DARK DESCENT]

   + Simplistic enemies are made terrifying on occasion by a strong use of music, visual effects, and sfx. The necessity of running, hiding, and relying on their stupidity makes hiding suspensful.

   + Sanity and other limited resources rush the player forward faster than they would like, while also making doing so a daunting task that raises suspension to enhance the fear factor.

   + Impressive story with lovecraft and other horror influences I wasn't expecting. The story, characters, and setting intertwine with the mechanics beautifully to create a strong sense of immersion, and drive in a sense of helplessness.

   + Puzzles are the main limiter that forces player exploration in times when they would really rather not, and work well with the sanity mechanic to feel satisfying to complete. Generally enjoyable, if also a factor in why the game isn't nearly as good on replay.

   + Game cranks up the driving "fear of the unknown" with several silly tactics, including relying and feeding into player assumptions that are totally false, mechanics that discourage really learning, and flat-out lying.


   ~ As mentioned, the 'lying' the game does enhances the fear on the first playthrough, but eventual learning makes it a limiting factor for replayability, and can feel like being made somewhat of a fool for causing your own misfortune.

   ~ Very short game, combined with other factors, means you will have a fun first go through, but replayability is almost non-existent. I would mark this as a negative, but the fact of the studio's size, issues I've heard of that occured during development, and the "short but sweet" package idea make it a more middling fact. Despite the short length of the first playthrough, this game still had a strong impact.

   ~ Some game breaking bugs exist, but due to constant saves, and a forgiving factor due to the issues mentioned above, they occured for me but were never a negative highlight (more like a footnote). Just be wary they can occur, especially if you take actions too fast during puzzles.


   - I marked 'non-replayability' as a mid factor, but certain are highlighted negatively. Previously, cinematic segments of flashbacks that drip-fed you story information were great and helped to establish it, but on replay they become slow crawls where it feels like ages to get through.

   - Again, I've marked many issues as mid factors due circumstantially, as they never became noticeably negative in my heart. Big however here though, as the hard mode takes every condolence I had and rips it apart. This mode has several aspects that greatly lessened my experience: limited saves due to limited resources means it can feel like the game isn't willing to recognize your knowledge of itself, the lack of constant saves means that gamebreaking bugs are a true nightmare to encouner rather than a footnote, and the tediousness of many aspects of the game become all too apparent by the time you play this mode (especially if you die at certain points and lose a great amount of time replaying bits).


As far as time per dollar go, don't expect a whole lot of value. In terms of that first playthrough, however, it will stick with you and is part of the reason it's a historical landmark in horror gaming. It's influence is palpable and is worth experiencing, and I could never 'not recommend' this game. Though, you might want to look to it's successors if you're not a fan of this style of late 2000's / early 2010's horror. 


----------------------------

[JUSTINE]

   + Going from The Dark Descent -> Justine grants back some of that fear of the unknown due to the new nature of it, and offers a quick fright for a short moment.

   + Despite my issues with the story, the tactic of unraveling it works much the same here, albeit to a lesser extent. The enemies are given a new angle of interest within this new setting.


   - Despite the new fear of unknown reintroduced, it fades quickly as not much new is actually done in terms of what The Dark Descent built its fear on. Does not remain scary for very long at all, even accounting for its length.

   - Although the main factor in the cause is due to Justine's size and scope, the story is pretty dreadful, especially in comparison to its base. Although fitting a story as quality as The Dark Descent's into Justine would be a daunting task, the general writing present here amounts to not much more than another horror story about a mentally ill person that's sooo crazy. Boring, overdone, and simply too easy, even for its time.

   - Justine is based around the idea of a psychiatric evaluation and the results of it based on certain trials the player goes through, but the end result of the eval is the same every time. Very much a missed opportunity, as well given the thematics of The Dark Descent.

   - The trials themselves are essentially obtuse, especially in comparison to The Dark Descent's puzzles (vague guestimations both in how you go about completing them and whether you actaully succeeded, unsatisfying).


As it comes with the base game, you're not looking for time/dollar value here, but time/enjoyment. Not horrible to play the first way through, like The Dark Descent, but it's replay value is even lower, possibly below the floor. You're better off playing any of the other dedicated Amnesia titles than this even once, let alone multiple times. Not an entirely un-worth playing if you really want to, however.

129612919.review:
In short: a really good scary game, but not much above that. A classic that is juuust beginning to show the technical and financial constraints of the team at that time, especially compared to their newer games.

[h2]Scary[/h2]
It is scary. It is moody and engrosing, it is at times creepy, at times lovecraftian, at times cruel and messed-up, and the atmosphere is impeccable. I'll elaborate a bit more in later parts of this review.
It is, in fact, [b][i]very[/i][/b] scary. So if you're feeling it's a bit too much for you, but want to carry on regardless, here's a bit of spoilery info to help: [spoiler]in most cases, enemies spawn with a distinct sound and despawn after searching; when the tense music stops, you're completely safe.[/spoiler]
So, it's scary, yes, but to what end? And the answer is: eh...

[h2]Story[/h2]
It is serviceable+. It is more or less coherent, it is almost not cringe ([spoiler]with the exception of certain real-world 16th century alchemists[/spoiler]), and the internal logic is well-maintained. The heavy lifting is mostly done by the atmosphere anyway. The story elevates the game from being a spooky castle-themed park, but it is neither emotionally nor intellectually rewarding. 
There are three endings that you can choose at the very end: the Ridiculous, the Almost-Satisfying and the Stupid.
I think the greatest strength of horror games is in their ability to tell unique stories - and this story is, frankly, not worth the horror experience. It doesn't ruin the game, as I've said, it's serviceable - but you don't play The Dark Descent for the story. There are games where you carry on through the dark hallways and unspeakable horrors for the sake of the story, but not this one - here the dark hallways and unspeakable horrors are the point, not the means.

[h2]Atmosphere[/h2]
Incredible. The sound design is amazing - footsteps, distant real or imagined screams, creaking floorboards, the surreal howling of [spoiler]the Shadow[/spoiler]. Each area is unique and [i]feels[/i] real. The locations are quite diverse too, from comforting and almost cozy, to dark, dirty and claustrophobic, to alien in scope and in their cruel architecture.
Yes, there are rough edges in other aspects of this game, but not here - the atmosphere is simply perfect.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Not amazing, not terrible - but the developers did far better in their later games. The gameplay involves mostly navigating areas, fetching stuff for puzzles and avoiding monsters. The latter is *boring*. 
The monsters are stupid as heck and due to some peculiarities of their implementation (remember that spoilery info at the beginning of the review?) most encounters are more of an annoyance than a challenge or a puzzle. Furthermore, due to the technical limitations and financial constraints the devs could neither hide the monsters in shadows well enough, nor implement the concepts in a more sophisticated way. So they are more like wax dolls then [...], and their design feels somewhat superficial, if still scary. Their concepts are incredible, but their implementation doesn't realize their potential fully. This applies to the (not much of a spoiler, it appers very early) [spoiler]Shadow too, a great concept that shines better in the scattered notes than in the actual gameplay.[/spoiler]
Overall, the game balances between terror and calm, between creepy and gory, unknown and explicit - and the developers haven't yet mastered this balancing act. This applies to the story and to the monsters too, without getting into spoilers. They still manage this delicate balance a lot better than many, many horror games - but there are also games that do it better, including the next Amnesia games and SOMA from the same devs.

The sanity mechanic is fun, but also it's better implemented in later games. And although it clearly tries to do so, it doesn't solve the problem of monsters being unimpressive up close.

The puzzles are fun. They don't require too much from your scared brain, but also pose a nice enough challenge. A big part of the puzzle is fetching stuff from the opposite sides of the map - which can be either "fun" (by horror standards) or annoying, depending on the current level and its inhabitants.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
I can only recommend this game on discount and if you're completely aware of what you're getting into. If you are only getting into horror games, that's not the best place to start. If you are interested in the Amnesia series, Rebirth has a far better and more dramatic story, more fun gameplay, a bit less scary (in my opinion, for the better), prettier and more coherently designed - thanks to a higher budget and more experience of the team at Frictional. 
Before I played this game, I was sad. Now I'm slightly annoyed, so that's an improvement. I wouldn't recommend it to my friends, but I will give it a thumbs-up out of respect for the devs and the influence this game had on the horror genre. And if you've played the other Frictional games and are in for a moody scary ride, go grab it.

"Amnesia: The Dark Descent" (TDD) is like a rollercoaster ride in an adult horror-themed amusement park. Created by Frictional Games, this game drags you in from the get-go into a spine-chilling experience that doesn't let go. It's certainly not for the faint of heart.

Imagine waking up in a gothic castle called the Brennenburg Castle with no memory of who you are or how you got there. You become Daniel, the amnesiac protagonist, and embark on a dark storyline filled with dark secrets, terrifying creatures, and moral dilemmas. The story unfolds subtly and immersively, keeping you on the edge of your seat.

What makes "Amnesia: The Dark Descent" unique is its focus on the player's vulnerability. You're not equipped with powerful weapons to face threats; you have to hide, run, and use your wits to survive! This lack of direct combat makes every encounter with lurking creatures extremely tense and frightening.

The dark, detailed graphics, along with eerie lighting, create an immersive atmosphere in the castle. The soundtrack and sound effects are equally unsettling, ramping up tension and fear in every corner of the game.

Amnesia: TDD has left a deep mark in the world of horror games. Its immersion, focus on psychological horror, intriguing narrative, and oppressive atmosphere make it a title that continues to be thrilling for those who enjoy the genre. If you dare to face your fears and delve into madness, this game is an exciting choice. 

Get ready for some scares along the way!

125639649.review:
Classic game of atmospheric horror and the beginnings of interactive psychological effects in horror gaming. If you are a horror gamer, then this game is truly a must play, even if just for nostalgia purposes. Obviously, graphics and scares have come a long way since Amnesia has been released, however it does a wonderful job at creating an intense feeling of pressure and dread during most of the game. These white-knuckle feelings make the puzzles just feel a bit more challenging and rushed and the world all that more intimidating (in a good way). Combined with the Insanity system in the game (be sure to avoid the darkness and staring at the denizens of the dark) Amnesia does a fantastic job at keep the gamer on their toes, keeping an eye on their matches and peaking around each corner.

Final thoughts, Amnesia delivers a very dark and grisly story line with obviously dated, but still nicely (in a horror sense) done visuals. The real compelling draw for Amnesia is the amazing atmospheric horror elements, art direction, ambiance, and the brilliant use of the insanity system making the gamer truly feel pressured and rushed making any "loot goblin" and explorer sweat as they try to explore each corner of the mansion. A must play of every horror game. 9/10

tl;dr 
It's a classic and if you want to get into horror games it is a great start.

Sadly I must add that I might have been ruined over the years by playing too many horror games to still feel scared while playing Amnesia. The concept of sanity is a great idea and it adds a lot to the whole atmosphere. In terms of puzzles, they are relatively straightforward and never too hard to hinder you in any way. 125404494.review:
Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a classic survival horror for very good reasons. It has a great atmosphere and environments, even if it mostly plays out in a big castle. The level design is great, both in how the levels are organized and their layout.
Sound design is great, which is critical for horror games. The graphics may be a bit outdated, but they’re still good overall. The story is good, and will keep you engaged until the game’s conclusion, which takes some hours to beat.
Enemy encounters are scary but fair. The puzzles can be a bit annoying, but they aren’t hard. It has a nice difficulty, not being too easy or too hard. You need to find and manage some resources, encouraging exploration.
It’s just a well thought and designed game from beginning to end, although some elements aren’t as good when looked back in retrospect. But don’t forget the game was released way back in 2010!
The game also includes achievements, including beating it on hard mode, which requires proper planning and patience, and playing Justine, a short expansion. Justine is a short game with a different story, that you must beat in one sitting, and can’t die.
The game also includes Remember, which are 5 short, written stories in a PDF file, and officially supports mods with custom stories that you can download and play as well.
However, given its age, it’s a bit expensive, but definitely grab it on sale and play it if you haven’t already.

"Amnesia: The Dark Descent" takes you down a road to horrors worse than death, and while you shuffle through the corridors of the old, decrepit manor of Bennenburg, you'll find yourself losing more than your sanity. 

In this amazing start to an amazing series, you take on the role of Daniel... an amnesiac who wakes up in castle Bennenburg with one sole purpose; recover his memory and escape that horrid, 14th century place with his mind intact. He soon figures he can telepathically communicate with a person called Alexander... who he'll soon realize, is not even human. 

Graphically, you can't expect much from a game made back in the 2000s; however, for its purpose, it delivers, horrifically so! The gameplay entails that you are completely defenseless against the Gatherers, Alexander's monstruous servants that roam the halls of the manor... and your only two weapons are the shadows, and your feet. You get two "health meters", one is your actual health and one is your sanity. Let me explain how these function: If you get slapped by a Gatherer, you lose health... Normally two slaps would end you, but sometimes you can escape after just that one first, really hurtful slap lol. Of course, by that point you'll have had a jumpscare and a heart attack, but after escaping make sure you hide in the shadows where the gatherer cannot see you with his cross-eyed dumb face. The insanity meter decreases when you look at horrid things; looking for a long period of time at a pile of eviscerated bodies, for example, will take quite the toll on your insanity! Looking at the Gatherers is itself quite scary. When you lose all of your health, you die, but when you lose all of your insanity, you will lay in the floor and all nearby Gatherers WILL KNOW EXACTLY WHERE YOU ARE... You can still escape them though! Get it?

The game also comes with a great, albeit quite short DLC called Justine that recounts the horrible deeds some Victorian Feminazi did to her suitors... but that's another story altogether. Furthermore, the game appearently comes with a book set in the Amnesia universe, written by Mikael Hedberg... I printed it out and started reading it every day at 2 in the morning... Man, I gotta say, it's the best DLC one could ever have to a horror game! Now let's talk about why this game gets a [b]7/10[/b] in my book. The puzzles are too easy to figure out... Now hold on, hold on! I can already see a ton of fans adding me to tell me how BS that is, but it's true! I figured out the most difficult puzzle in the entire game (making Agrippa's potion) simply by looking at Daniel's notes, and nothing else. That's still not enough for a score of 7? Try the game's CRASHING everytime you alt-tab... The game crashed like a million times while I was playing it, worse yet it did when I hadn't saved in ten minutes of gameplay.

I recommend all horror fans to play this game as the occasional jumpscares will keep you on your toes. Also if you like being chased in videogames, this is for you. I mean, there is nothing better in the entire world... than being chased by a couple of demonic figures, with their jaws falling off... So sexy and underrated LMFAO!

[h1] The Truth Hides In The Darkness [/h1]
 
Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a survival horror/adventure video game by Frictional Games. The game features a protagonist named Daniel exploring a dark and foreboding castle called Brennenburg, while trying to maintain his sanity by avoiding monsters and unsettling events.
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]

    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]The graphics are still good and hold up well. The atmosphere is absolutely terrifying and done perfectly. You truly feel like you are stuck in this cold, dark castle alone. The visuals are dark, and have a classic medieval feel to it (well you are in a castle). The monster design is pretty spooky although it’s not the scariest thing I've seen in a horror game, but it does a good job on setting fear into you which is a big plus for me. One huge complaint is the motion blue. It’s so bad in this game. It triggers when you are in fear and it gives me motion sickness. Luckily you can turn this off in the settings.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]The gameplay is pretty simple here. You have to conserve your light source and find oil and tinder to light up parts of the castle. The puzzles are actually pretty clever and can be challenging at times which is great to see. You also have amazing environmental storytelling in this game, being able to hear what happened in certain rooms can be somewhat also visually telling if you imagine the scenario. You do have a sanity meter as well, so if you have a weird motion blur or any other visual/audio cues (or you can check your meter), then you are vulnerable to the monster as you are more likely to be found.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]This is a story about Daniel and not having any memory of why he is there. Through the story you will find more about yourself and some scary twists through the game. It’s actually a really good story, just make sure to read the journals and documents because that’s how you will learn more about the plot (which may turn off some people, but I enjoyed it). This was actually a pretty good story, not the best but it’s a great one that feels pretty unique.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]This game took me about 13 hours to complete. You also have an extra expansion called “Justine” in the game for free which adds like an hour with some replayability to it.[/td]

        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The ambient sounds can be really scary. From distant screaming and unheard of noises in the distance can make you really paranoid.     [/tr]

        [td]One annoying bug is the odd frame drops you may see in this game. If you Alt+Tab and join back it can lag your game. Even sometimes reading a document can cause this or an event trigger. It doesn’t last long (thankfully) so it’s not game breaking. The other weird bug is when the monster kills you and you load back a save, the monster disappears which feels like an exploit or could just be a rare bug (I did have this twice on my playthrough).[/td]
    [/tr]

124635910.review:
Muchos juegos de survival horror limitan el componente de supervivencia al concepto del matar o morir. El jugador asume que el único modo de perdurar en un ambiente hostil y terrorífico es con la ayuda de las armas, y de aquí en adelante todo se reduce a cuan grande es el arma que desbloqueas. En un tiempo en el que el survival horror es cada vez más como una película de acción, Amnesia: The Dark Descent vuelve a las raíces del concepto llevándonos al horror psicológico de un protagonista vulnerable, sin opción de pelear, siendo su rol el de una presa que debe escapar para ganar todo el tiempo posible. Este principio de jugabilidad se combina con un ambiente sombrío y desolado, transitando entre castillos del siglo XIX, misteriosas criptas del norte de África, sistemas de cañerías, morgues, prisiones y sangrientos lugares de culto, mezclando ficción con realidad en una narrativa casi literaria. El gameplay es de reglas simples, pero su dificultad viene en parte de la continua tensión de enemigos que persiguen, lo que es especialmente frustrante en dificultades altas, pero al final logra entregar lo que promete.

Los ambientes son variados, pero envueltos en una sensación de claustrofobia en la cual la oscuridad ambiental es el factor principal. La mayoría de los lugares no pueden ser bien explorados sin una lámpara de gas, y los sonidos de los alrededores, cargados de cortinas musicales inquietantes, pueden ser tanto una fuente de orientación como de ansiedad. Uno de los puntos fuertes de Amnesia TDD es el gran nivel de interacción con múltiples objetos, algunos cuidadosamente diseñados y llenos de simbolismos históricos o aspectos que contribuyen a la trama. Los modelos de los enemigos son grotescos, diseñados no para una apreciación detallada, sino que para una repulsión que haga mantenerse alejado. Durante la mayor parte del juego, la transición entre paisajes es fluida y puede cautivar a los jugadores más curiosos por varias horas.

Hay visiones encontradas sobre la trama. Algunos pueden pensar que falla en mantener el interés del jugador dado lo confusa que es, mientras otros piensan que aunque es buena no logra intensidad. Para mí, la historia se entrega tan bien como podría esperarlo de un juego de horror de un jugador. Lleno de puzles, misterios y revelaciones repentinas, la historia tiene una narrativa no lineal pensada para ser reconstruida pieza por pieza a partir de dispersas notas escritas por el protagonista con asombrosa narrativa y sentimiento. Se siente como leer páginas de un libro escrito por un individuo aproblemado, lleno de miedos, arrepentimientos y deseos de venganza que lo ponen al borde de la locura. Más aún, dentro de los archivos del juego se pueden encontrar fascinantes historias cortas que contribuyen considerablemente a una comprensión más amplia de la trama y que pueden resultar de interés por múltiples horas.

La jugabilidad es el aspecto más distintivo de Amnesia TDD y, en general, de la mayoría de los títulos de Frictional Games. Un protagonista indefenso es lanzado a un mundo de horrores sin armas y con iluminación limitada, debiendo navegar cuidadosamente evitando peligrosos enemigos que actúan como incansables depredadores. Es así de simple. Sin embargo, hay una mecánica con directo impacto en la supervivencia y que se relaciona a la psicología del protagonista como narrador de su historia: la cordura. Mientras más baja la cordura, más distorsionado es el entorno, más asustado está el protagonista y más probabilidad hay de ser encontrado y asesinado por los enemigos. Mantener la cordura requiere estar malabareándose entre estar cerca de áreas con luz, mantenerse alejado de los enemigos y resolver puzles desafiantes, pero no demasiado difíciles. Si bien es innovadora e interesante en dificultades casuales, la cordura puede volverse fácilmente una mecánica frustrante en modo difícil, considerando que cuando baja a cero tu personaje está muerto y debes volver a partir de un punto quizás muy atrás en el tiempo. Otro aspecto mejorable del juego son las interacciones con obstáculos y movimiento del jugador que a veces se siente incómodo, llevando a pequeños y torpes errores que la mayoría de las veces son fatales. Esto junto con la imperiosa necesidad de juntar yesqueros en modo difícil pueden hacer sentir el juego como una rutina, ser artificialmente difícil y molesto, y casi imposible de jugar sin una guía (lo que por supuesto le quita toda la inmersión y el desafío). Sin embargo, debe rescatarse el potencial de rejugabilidad a través del DLC Justine (que tiene una corta pero interesante historia) y las historias personalizadas que abren un mundo de posibilidades fabricadas por el jugador que son amigables para desarrollar al igual que en grandes títulos como Half-Life.

Amnesia TDD definitivamente no es un juego para todos, dado lo terrorífico que puede ser o lo aburrido que puede ser percibido si se aguantan los elementos de horror. Sin embargo, pienso que le da un nuevo aire al cada vez más trillado género del survival horror con ambiente evocativos, narrativa ejemplar y jugabilidad desafiante.

124144504.review:
I never played this game when it came out, I never watched any “Let’s Play”’s of it when PewDiePie & Markiplier playing it was on trending page, I had zero nostalgia bias.
But having played this game for the first time blind at 22, I can safely say this isn’t just one of my favorite Horror games of all time, this is one of my favorite games in general.

What I love:
- This game is perfectly balanced, you are never too unfairly crushed, but you are never getting by so easily, you are always on the perfect line of challenge where when you die, it is 100% your own fault as a player, you didn’t manage your supplies correctly? Manage them better.
You knew an enemy was nearby but you ran carelessly around the corner without even leaning to check? Take your time to hear enemies & maybe crouch more often.
& balancing is not an easy thing to do in games, especially in Horror.
Some Indie Horror games can be absolute bull$&@! where it’s too crushingly difficult to the point of an unfair advantage like having an intentional chase sequence, but you are barely given any room to hide.
But some Horror games can be too easy where you can run past enemies like they’re a sack of bricks, or you are given so much health to the point of fearing damage is gone.
Seeing this so perfectly accomplished in Amnesia genuinely impressed me & depressed me for the fact so many games with good potential get this wrong.
- The story has a perfect balance between story & gameplay.
The story goes seamlessly with the gameplay, not always removing you from progress in an obnoxious fashion, but instead working together through a mix of intriguing & easily comprehensible notes, and occasional visual storytelling through disturbing implications shown in the environments
- The story itself.
The story had me roped in from the very beginning, from when the protagonist Daniel stumbles out, seeming very shaken & disturbed, but without memory.
And of course up til you start piecing together why he is here through all the notes & environmental implications he finds.
Even though you don’t even I guess properly see other NPC characters throughout the whole game, the voices alone that you hear through the memories & seeing the notes written by others exudes so much personality you can easily grasp.
Alexander maybe one of the greatest Horror villains perhaps in just Horror fiction in general, into the grand sphere of both Horror games, films, & novels.
He is somehow both charismatic, hatable, disturbed, disturbingly confident, & disturbingly trustworthy-sounding all at once through how he talks & the way he words things.
Overall, it is a very very disturbing but fascinating structurally solid story with an unmatched pace.
- The gameplay.
I used to not be a big fan of Walking Sim or rather Horror games where you are unable to defend yourself, I always gave out unfair judgement of how it would be boring being unable to fight back or be too unfair.
But this game not only proved me wrong, but actually made me even more interested in Defenseless Horror games.
Funny enough, Amnesia was actually once planned in development to include a Bow & Arrow and even a Flintlock Pistol at some point, while that sounds fun on paper.
Amnesia ultimately is a better game without the ability to defend yourself.
It truly immerses you into the feeling of utter terror being unable to defend yourself when all you can do is run & hide, & while that in itself sounds like a repetitious concept, Amnesia does it very well where it cuts back on the commonly boring aspect of waiting around until an enemy goes away, in turn for having the enemy walk away quicker than it usually would.
& the thing is, this in canon makes sense, as terrifying as The Gatherers are in Amnesia, they are not exactly intelligent creatures, & that makes sense, they’re mangled up hideous abominations that were likely man-made & imperfect cause of that, they have the psychology of an infant where if an infant no longer sees a person who is hiding, they believe they don’t exist.
& while that makes them sound like pushovers, believe it or not, it doesn’t.
These enemies are still terrifying & can DESTROY you if you are not careful around them, they maybe limited psychologically, but you are also limited to their claustrophobic environment, so in a way, you are leveled on their playing field.
This is kind of random, but I also really enjoy the way the game controls, it really brings a fun degree of interactivity to drag your mouse to interact with certain contraptions without coming off as gimmicky.

What I don’t like:
- ….

Honestly, I was never frustrated with this game, I didn’t have a moment where I called bullshit on a death, I didn’t have a moment where I found a glaring plot hole in the story, & I never crashed or glitched once.
I will admit, a couple of the puzzles & objectives could be a tiny bit cryptic, but honestly, that is moreso my fault because I kinda suck at puzzles.
So I won’t count it against the game.

With that, I’d give this game a 👍+
Even if you aren’t a Horror game nut like I am, I still believe you should give this game a try.

TL;DR
IT’S A REALLY WELL BALANCED INTENSE SURVIVAL HORROR EXPERIENCE WITH A HIGHLY-DISTURBING BUT ENGAGING PSYCHOLOGICAL HORROR MYSTERY STORY, MANY REALLY HEART ATTACK-INDUCING SCARY MOMENTS & MANY #&$!UP STORY MOMENTS.
SERIOUSLY IF YOUR KID WANTS TO PLAY THIS GAME BECAUSE THEY SAW SOMEBODY ON YOUTUBE PLAY IT, DON’T LET THEM, THERE IS UNCUT PENISES.

124136118.review:
Amnesia is a horror game made by developers who understand what makes a horror game scary. It's not about jumpscares, it's not about gratuitous gore, it's not about a bodycount. It's about atmosphere, filling the player with terror without even putting their character in any real danger the majority of the time. The sound design, environments, ambiance, all come together to make the player's imagination do all the work for them. The fear that something horrible could be right behind you, above you, in a room beside you immerse you in a world of terror.

This game uses Lovecraftian elements effectively to make for a compelling and curious game that will have players curious about what exactly is going on long after they've finished playing, and serves the game's narrative and immersion well. It reinforces the terror, making the game scary on psychological as well as physiological level. The player is completely helpless to defend themselves against the physical threats, as well as the psychological threats, and this is an excellent means to fully pull the player into the experience.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent is the gold standard by which to measure horror games, and I strongly recommend it to anyone looking to turn off all the lights, silence their home, and lose themselves in a deeply unsettling experience.

YouTubers of different caliberes and IQs made this game extremely popular, so its no surprise that this game is still relevant and also - gave birth to a lot of titles throughout the years...

You wake up in a long hallway, cant remember a thing, do not understand what the hell is going on...and neither is your character - Daniel. Light up everything, look for "batteries" for your Lantern, hide/run from monsters, deduce puzzles and make your way to the very depths of the castle - to choose one of three endings.

Probably the best puzzle horror game ever made.

The darkness, limited light mechanics, sound effects, soundtrack and camera effects are all masterfully crafted for each spot with a buildup to slowly instill terror in your mind, one you can't escape. For maximum effect, adjust the gamma how the game asks you to, play at night, alone, lights off and with headphones on the highest comfortable volume you can handle.

Each section of the castle is beautifully crafted, filled with interactible objects and their atmosphere adapted to the horrors that happened there. Even with its dated graphics, they still look really good.

The story may go over your head if you're always too scared while playing. But it's a really well developed story. Take your time, don't rush it.

The object mechanics are on point. You are able to grab most objects, rotate them and throw them giving a bigger sense of freedom. The door opening mechanic is simple yet perfect, dreading every time you try to open one.

The puzzles are pretty good and satisfying to solve. Some may require more patience and attention which sometimes can be hard to have when immersed in the game's terrorizing atmosphere.

The only negative part I can point out is near the final. It seemed kind of rushed and not as organic as the rest of the game was.

Amnesia: The Dark Descent is an incredible horror experience that will remain a classic of the genre for many many years to come, imitated by many but matched by few (even its own sequels don't hold a candle to the original.) Amnesia:TDD is the walking sim, stealth peek-a-boo, monster corridor grand daddy and it will be hard for any others to topple it from its throne. 

Amnesia starts with the character Daniel waking up with...amnesia, you find yourself stuck in a creepy castle with only a letter written by yourself for company. 

The story then unfolds mostly through notes and flashbacks as you uncover the secrets of the castle and its occupants, you solve puzzle and get chased by some horrific monsters. The story itself is more in the background and to understand what is happening you need to pay attention to the notes, flashbacks and environment. 

Gameplay is simple, keep the lights on or go insane, solve puzzle and hide from monsters, it is so simple yet effective and this gameplay loop has spawned many a copy cat. 

Graphics are perfectly fitting for a game that came out in 2010 plus you spend most of the game in darkness anyway, really it's the style and tone that elevates this game. 

Really my only gripe is that some rooms are difficult to navigate due to the fact they all look the same and also the fact you're pretty much in constant darkness. 

Whilst I may prefer Soma's style of horror and the story of that game Amnesia really is the swansong of Frictional Games and it is a crying shame the sequels haven't come close to the greatness of the original. Easily a top ten horror game and one all horror fans should experience.

Beware: humor lies ahead! Also, some minor early game story spoilers.

Dear Daniel: Have you ever wanted to do a hands-on study of the intersection between occultism, 19th century torture methods, and gothic architecture? No? Well too bad, Danny Boy, because you are waking up in Castle Brennenberg University with a terrible case of amnesia and being forcefully enrolled in our hippest new class, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, anyway. In your journey with this wondrous class you will do an in-depth exploration of the world's most architecturally unstable classic Gothic castle, along the way solving devious puzzles and desperately hiding and running away from shrek's uglier (and more violent) cousins, who have all the pleasantness and perceptiveness of a sack of worms. Oh, and the whole time you are being hunted by what can only be described as an especially relentless form of wall-crawling acne. In your travels you will find various notes left left by your pre-amnesiac in miraculously perfect order to tell the narrative of how you came to be in the most haunted corner of the Earth.  

During your time in this class you will constantly find yourself losing your marbles, due to events including but not limited to: hearing mysterious tormented screams echoing throughout the castle, experiencing vague trauma flashbacks half the times you open a door, the wind blowing out your torch for 27th time, gawking at corpses, fondling instruments of torture for no good reason (seriously, what is wrong with you?), looking at the Shreks, hiding in the darkness so you don't look at the shreks, and, my personal favorite, hallucinations caused by how many marbles you have lost already. 

Your professor for this class will be Alexander, the Duke of Brennenberg, an expert in classic Gothic villainy with a voice to match (some say he studied under Count Dracula himself!). The Teaching Assistant for your class section will be a poorly cleaned iron maiden in the center of a poorly lit room, which you can decide to shove yourself in for no good reason (it's not going to further the plot or bring any sort of reward, but now that I have told that you can you are going to do it anyway because you can, you senseless dolt). For your final project in this class your pre-amnesiac self has chosen for you to take bloody vengeance against your professor, Alexender of Brennenberg, for reasons that are still a mystery for you. You will learn more about that from the notes your pre-amnesiac self littered around the castle, each of which raise far more questions than they do answers.

This game was very ahead of its time despite the fact that it had an extremely small developer team and was limited by what games were capable of at the time. Against all odds, this game made an insanely huge impact on the survival horror genre and set the framework for many other amazing games that would come out in later years. It's also very nostalgic for me as many youtubers I grew up watching started out playing games like Amnesia and other horror games. With that said I already had a rough idea of the story playing it myself now but it did not take away from the experience much. The story is still pretty solid and has an interesting way of slowly revealing Daniel's memories  by scattering his diary entries around various rooms in the Brennenburg Castle, which is by far one of the most iconic locations in video games. Many have tried to replicate the eerie medieval look in other horror games but it's never quite had the same impact as this game. Another thing worth mentioning about this game is its enemies, they're pretty intimidating and require mostly stealth gameplay to play around, but there's always that risk you could take of breaking into a sprint in attempts to reach a new area or safe spot before it catches you. I find this cat and mouse style gameplay very effective to this day. The gameplay mixed with the disturbing models (The Grunts being the most recognizable) create a very suspenseful experience. To sum up my thoughts I really love this game and think that anyone who's even remotely a fan of survival horror should check it out even if there's currently no remake or modernized versions. I've edited my original review as I feel this game is still worth playing through at least once, especially for the atmosphere, but it is drastically overrated. 

It's telling when in the achievements section of the game, less than 10% of players actually beat it, but felt free to review it. This is not an overwhelmingly positive in my book man

It doesn't compare to the more modern suspense/horror games, and it doesn't even compare to the older ones (Fear 2005, Dead Space 2008, Silent Hill 1999...)

The game starts with a lingering intensity. Some of the puzzles can be really satisfying, and the layout of the castle itself is almost beautiful in some areas. The sanity meter is also a really unique idea! 

But all of those pros fade after the first hour or two. Any semblance of intensity or atmosphere fades after you spend hours back tracking through the same areas running out of oil and tinder-boxes. Frustrating. 
In the latter half of the game, the monsters are not scary at ALL. They are purely frustrating, and serve as an annoying roadblock to your objectives, nothing more or less. You really start wishing you could pick up a saw or something and just fight back but "Huehue my sanity cough cough."

This final gripe is totally subjective, but I'll leave it here either way. (Spoilers) The torture rooms, dude. I did not need to know any of the shit they threw in there. Absolutely gratuitous. Adding a section where we show a demonstration of a woman getting her bones broken and subsequently raped (or suggested) is COMPLETELY UNNECESSARY. Hearing screams of dying children in the final cut-scenes... it just made me want to turn the game off. I've played my fair share of horror games, but there's an important difference between real aesthetic experiences, and torture porn. Joseph Campbell described this kind of art (shock, visual) as pornography, and that's what it is. Immature, and completely unnecessary.

[h1] Amnesia: The Dark Descent [/h1]
Amnesia: The Dark Descent's story is an interesting one. The monsters are certainly creepy and they are made even more terrifying by the fact that you are unable to fight them. Your only choices are to run away or hide. Although, I should say [i] technically [/i] you can't fight them as you are able to stagger them for a brief second by throwing an object at them. The pacing is pretty good as the story doesn't feel rushed. The Dark Descent certainly presents an eerie tone quite early on.

This game is also interesting by the fact that you are able to pickup and interact with a good majority of objects in the game and it's mechanic for how you use/interact with said objects with your mouse or controller. For example, when the game makes you do the rotating motion with your mouse or analog stick to turn a valve. I like when games do that. Makes them feel more interactive.

The Dark Descent is made even more enjoyable because you can play custom stories that other people have made or you can even make your own. There are some decent custom stories out there. Unfortunately, the lack of Steam Workshop support does mean you have to go out and find them, but it's not too hard to find any. You can just google "[b] Amnesia Custom Stories [/b]" and you will most likely find a link to sites like [b] moddb [/b] where you can find custom stories or some other mods for the game. Overall, Amnesia: The Dark Descent was a fun and chilling experience.

This game reminds me of:

+Kholat (during the parts where stuff is chasing you).
+INFRA (due to the general complexity and type of puzzles involved and during those times when you are down in sewers near poisonous mushrooms; a possible reference to Amnesia).
+Shadowgate 64: Trials of the Four Towers (This version of Shadowgate had a similar color palette (dark and dingy) but had more obtuse puzzles but doesn’t get as dark or violent as Amnesia).
-Agony: UNRATED (Agony, like Amnesia, has an unhealthy fascination with torture).


What I thought about this game:

+ Great sound effects which put you on edge.

+ Unlike many other horror games, this one was not frustrating.

+ Responsive controls which recognized an additional gaming mouse button (though the key configuration menu didn’t know what to call it and so left the space blank when it was assigned).

+ No major bugs.

+ I don’t want to give anything away but I love how the environment and your perceptions change a little bit when your character’s sanity is low.

+/- The plot is sort of creepy but not extremely because your main antagonist is, afterall, just a man (and this is not much of a spoiler because you know this from the beginning of the game). The game takes place in the early 19th century and, well, men can be killed pretty easily. His castle has stairs. Toss him down some and it will look to the doofus police investigators of the time that it was an accident. I bet stuff like this probably happened a LOT in those days. There’s some supernatural stuff going on but, while it looks like a spreading mess, it doesn’t really look creepy. It just looks like a mess some poor servant is going to have to clean up. It would’ve been better (and less confusing) if the ‘shadow’ following you really looked like an impenetrable shadow which no amount of light could dispel.

+/- Good puzzles which are not too obtuse but not overly easy either. Unfortunately there are some red-herring puzzle solutions here and there (like a room full of boxes which I could move but which I didn’t need to) and there are times when it can be hard to know what the game wants you to do next.

+/- Dark and dingy colors attempt to make the game creepy but also make it boring to look at in many places. The colors also often seemed calming and comfortable to me and so reduced my tension even when it was dark (but then I also tend to find darkness to be calming rather than creepy).

+/- This game is fairly linear. You don’t usually feel lost because there are too few options concerning where you can go. Any place you don’t need to go or shouldn’t go to soon are almost always blocked off. Sometimes you need to travel to the same area repeatedly (which is realistic). I never felt lost or scared of getting lost in a hostile environment and so I never felt out-of-control.

+/- I liked the classic idea of exploring a creepy castle but there wasn’t enough evidence of a (perhaps blighted) family life from an earlier time. The setting wasn’t detailed enough to seem real but instead felt oddly generic.

+/- The music is good for the game but not extremely interesting in itself. I wouldn’t try to get a soundtrack of it.

+/- Amnesia’s voice acting is mediocre. The spoken dialogue reminds me of character-stereotypes in Disney movies. You can tell the game’s main antagonist is evil just by hearing his voice. This caused the game to lose any sense of grittiness and thus real danger. It felt too silly instead.

+/- Amnesia has 3 endings but they depend entirely on what you do at the very end so it is easy to simply reload your save file repeatedly and get all 3 of them. The game’s plot causes none of the endings to be very satisfying because by the end of the game you [spoiler]find out your character is a total douche and probably doesn’t deserve to continue living[/spoiler]

-The game didn’t usually make me feel very weak or powerless. I can run fairly fast without getting tired. I almost always managed to have enough tinderboxes (basically matches) to light up anything I needed. I could move and throw heavy boxes and books around with ease (and I often did so). 

-Making lots of noise usually failed to attract monsters to my area unless they were already nearby. The monsters instead showed up in certain, fairly predictable locations or after I had obtained a critical item here and there. My biggest scares occurred when monsters appeared in rooms I did not expect to find them in and this only happened twice. 

- Running away from monsters and going just one room away and hiding behind a corner in the darkness was so extremely effective the monsters seemed laughably stupid. When they did catch me, the death scenes were not very creepy. I play a lot of games so I’m used to dying in them. The deaths in Unreal Tournament 1999 are more gruesome and scary. Surprise me with a more unusual (and yet not irritating) experience. I’m honestly not sure what would work well. Maybe instead of dying my character should get increasingly disfigured and crippled somehow, thus resulting in a worse ending later in the game.

-In the final scene you can see the main antagonist’s [spoiler]little tiny penis[/spoiler]. If you have a sense of humor similar to mine this will probably strike you as being sort of distracting, like seeing [spoiler]Dr. Manhattan’s penis in Watchmen[/spoiler]. I mean, what exactly are you going to be looking at during this scene? At the very least, the antagonist, [spoiler]while channeling loads of throbbing, occult power, should have sported a huge, erect dong[/spoiler] instead. Anyhow, it was pretty distracting and detracted from the ending scene. And no, as a bisexual, I don’t have to ‘grow up.' [spoiler]Exposed penises are inherently distracting[/spoiler].

- Amnesia has an ethically disturbing fascination with real-world methods of torture and execution which have actually been used and should probably not have included such detailed depictions of these methods. This helps no one and doesn't improve the game.

119667012.review:
Amnesia is an interesting game to say the least.  One hailed as a horror classic and an important milestone in the genre.  It’s not for me to say whether it is or isn’t as its influence can be seen very clearly in modern horror games such as Outlast and Alien: Isolation.  At least these are the closest in terms of spirit and gameplay.  Many other horror games would pop out just from the simple success of Amnesia such as Slender and SCP, horror games as a whole got a big boost.

See this game didn’t just kick off the survival horror with no weapons game it restarted the entire genre.

This game really makes me realize just how old I am.  Spoiler alert but the game isn’t too scary, like at all.  Which surprised me.  I’ve had this game for the better part of 8 years now collecting dust in my steam catalog.  I had tried a few times to play it but always got too scared and uninstalled it.  I had built it up for years as being too scary, only finally touching it again due to the game drought only to end up running through most of it.

The biggest problem is that enemies, the things that are supposed to scare you, will just despawn.  Unlike games like Alien and Outlast that have a wandering baddy at all times to keep you on edge you can hide and eventually the monster will just exit the area.

It doesn’t even take that long, only around a minute of waiting and pop, he’s gone, leaving you to run around until you figure out the puzzle or progress to the next area.  And as long as you keep your sanity up you won’t have to deal with him again, which is fairly easy as I ended the game with around 40 tinderboxes and a consistent 9 oil canisters.

Then there are the puzzles themselves which are frustrating to no end.  It seems like most people had an easy walk with them but I spend 90% of the game running around trying to figure out puzzles rather than being afraid.  The problem is some puzzles use items like a point and click while others use physics props.

In two different parts you need to clog a gear to stop a machine, with the first one you stick a pipe from your inventory into it while the other one you physically throw a rock into it (despite having another piece of broken pipe in your inventory).  Or how some bridges are lowered with a lever while others just have a rock thrown at them.  It jumps between these two different mechanics often enough, constantly throwing off your thought process.   It can be very confusing and frustrating but then again that may just be my own stupidity.

The real saving grace of the game is its story and atmosphere which are both top notch.

All this seems to point to a game that is somewhat middling.  Doing some things right and some wrong, sort of evening out into this middle ground.  I mean if you make a horror game that’s not scary you must have messed something up.  But what does this have to do with my age?

Well, for some reason I got it into my head that this game came out in 2004 when it actually came out in 2010.  Quite a bit more recent than I had expected which made me less lenient on it.  I mean surely there had been good horror games before it at this point, right?  They may have repopularized it but surely there had been standouts before it that could better claim the title of revitalizing the horror genre.

You had Dead Space and…  Silent hill though that was the early 2000s.  F.E.A.R. doesn’t really count, nor Bioshock or Condemned.  Looking through the list of horror games post Amnesia is shockingly low and what is there isn’t exactly scary.  Silent Hill 2 comes the closest but apart from that there is next to nothing.

It wasn’t Amnesia that was behind a trend or just getting a lot of credit because of the famous people who played it.  It was me who was behind.  I’ve grown old and I sort of just assumed this was one of those older games from the mid 2004.  I thought  Pewd’s had just dug it up and popularized it.

It might be a bit clunky at parts and when compared to other games that came out in 2010 it’s certainly not the best looking.  But there really isn’t much like it before and still not much after.  It was really unique and set the precedent for horror games to come.

I believe art should be seen through a lens of the time.  A game like Half Life is a masterpiece but it can’t stand up to a game like Red Dead 2.  It can’t be said that it’s a worse game or less of a game due to the limitation of the time.  That’s why they can both stand together as great games despite one being a huge, well polished experience and the other being a linear first person shooter.

That’s why, despite its shortcomings, it is well worth a playthrough and I recommend you check it out.

7/10 - Amnesia is a game that was even a little dated for the time in terms of visuals and gameplay but its impact on the medium, its excellent storytelling, and next to none atmosphere makes it stand out as one of the better titles to come out of 2010.

For as simple as the game is, it holds up surprisingly well.
Even after the huge burst of relevance it received more than a decade back, after all the memes and how it got milked to death for Youtube content through its main story and custom stories, Amnesia the Dark Descent holds up as a very nice, compact little horror game. 

And what's most surprising to me, as a horror game veteran, is how FRIENDLY this game is to beginners. Beyond puzzles which are largely spelled out for you through notes that can be easily ignored in most cases through trial and error, the biggest shock to me was how easily avoided the enemies are. Most disappear on revisits to rooms, many of the beginning segments rely on "Poofers" meant to jumpscare you and catch new players off guard, and maps are designed meticulously so that Players can hide relatively easily from them when they are ambushed. If you are even mildly precautious of your actions, they generally won't threaten you. In fact... my only death in the game was from a scripted one near the end. 

Really goes to show how much the fear of the unknown plagued players back in the day.
With the "Insanity" mechanic in tow, simply not knowing what to expect or how the game worked really put fear into people where it wasn't necessary, but that's to the game's credit.

Now that water monster chase on the other hand? Still gets me.
This game is a great starter horror for newer fans to the genre, easily would recommend it.

Simple review details - I rank games on an out of 10 basis, granting up to 3 points in 3 categories, as well as a last, single point from my own self, depending on my experience with it.

GAMEPLAY

Amnesia is a First Person walking simulator with horror elements, however, surprisingly, it does not acutally fall into the trap often associated with horror games – that being the cheap jumpscare – and instead presents the Player with a very real sensation of dread.

That is achieved by making the Player Character (PC) incapable of fighting back, relatively slow and also very fragile, whilst also placing said PC in an environment that features entities that will assault the PC, will chase after it and will do their best to kill it.

In addition to that, the Player is provided a few tools to make it through – those being means of illuminating the world, as darkness actively makes playing the game harder by taking away responsiveness from the controls and smudging the screen.

On top of that, there are a number of puzzles that will need to be solved, though they are all quite simple and rudimentary – which is more than enough when coupled with the constant threat of an attack.

Incredibly, while this might appear very simple and barebones, it has been mixed masterfully by the evelopers and has led into the creation of a fantastic set of scrambled eggs.
3/3

PRESENTATION

Amnesia, as mentioned, fills the Player with dread – and that is not only achieved via the powerlessness of the PC, it is also done through the implementation of visuals and sounds. The game features  a 3D environment that is shrowded in shadow, with there being very few sources of light, which creates safe spaces – those that are illuminated – and dangerous zones – those that are not.

The dark spots are filled with the unknown and with uncertainty, which is inherently frightening. Then, that is coupled with the spectacular ambience (and the pronounced lack of music in most situations) to start building upon the Player’s fright and unease, generating tension and dread.

By the time an enemy shows up, there is no loud pang of a piano or a strumming of strings – there is a slow, winding up screeching sound (or perhaps musical track) that grows in intensity, and there is the monster that appears out of nowhere, unsettling by merit of its uncanny appearance. In fact, all characters that show up in the game have this uncanny appearance which only elevates the sensation of unease that the Player is forced to experience.

As a horror game that features close to no jump-scares, Amnesia winds up being impressively well presented, instilling a phenomenal amount of dread into the Player that translates into proper horror. Lastly, the voice acting is also very competent.
3/3

STORY

Amnesia gives the Player a story about redemption, but also a story about ancient beings that were present in the obscure periods of human history. It presents a mystery that does not get entirely unraveled by the end of the story – if anything, the mystery only grows more interesting as the conclusion of the tale told by this game is reached – yet, at the same time, the questions that the Player happens to have at the start of the game are, mostly, answered.

So Amnesia gives the Player some satisfaction while also tickling them in a most scintillating manner, whilst also featuring a plethora of approaches to presenting the story – be it via notes, be it via memories, be it via small tidbits that show up every now and then, be it via visual transformations of the environment and, lastly, via the PC’s actions themselves.
3/3

Legendary Point

Does this game get the legendary point, so craved and wanted by all and none at the same time? Does this game, which I’ve so far been gently caressing and kissing gingerly in an effort to convey just how good it is, get the point? I mean… yes. 1/1

CONCLUSION

10/10. Wow. Maybe I didn’t plan on giving this game a 10 when I played it, but now that I’ve had it wallowing in my brain soup, I suppose the rough diamond it was has ended up polished to perfection. This game is phenomenal, and I’d urge anyone with a strong enough stomach and an inclination to play games to play it. If not play it, watch someone play it, at least so that they can experience the story.

 I place it in a frame, surrounded by lights. As though it were upon a king’s head on the day of his coronation, I extend my hands towards it, a wordless prayer on my lips. An achievement, undoubtedly, one that I can not fathom. And a copy of it I proudly tuck away under my belt, to be displayed as a treasure unlike any other.
--

Amnesia is a horror game, where what you cannot see, scares you more than what you can see. It puts you on the brink of madness and horror and keeps you there.
The story is really addictive, and the protagonist is an Englishman suffering from amnesia, stumbling through a dark castle in search of answers. But this answer is unlikely to bring you joy. However, while the story is scary enough, the true brilliance of this game is the way it injects you with a feeling of utter helplessness and despair. You never feel like you have options other than to run and hide, and even these options feel temporary by simply postponing the inevitable for a little longer.
No game I've ever played has used the dark so effectively. Everything in this game works to create a real feeling of fear. The sound and graphics are great and the game mechanics are really cool. Pushing and pulling objects, sliding chairs in front of doors all work to give you a real horror experience.

115253298.review:
Ah, yes. The game that pioneered the "Let's play" genre and made personas like PewDiePie into some of the most popular people online. Other than that the game popularized the run-and-hide horror genre (I consider this an advanced walking simulator with elements of survival horror). While not the best Survival Horror has to offer this game is a great example of great ambience and sound design. Although the story isn't something amazing but it is interesting enough to get you to the end of the game. 
The highlights are the voice acting and the ambience and sound effects. This is something most horror games fail at and yet it is the most important part. Because it gives the game a "soul". You feel connected and immersed in the game, that way you get scared the most. The monster designs are alright, the most famous design is of the Servant Grunt and I've never considered them scary, even in 2010 when the game came out they looked like a pigman of some sort and they are mostly funny to me. Overall the game is solid. You have just enough resources to go by and enemy bahavior is consistent. The sfx and voice acting + music is great but other than the chasing the game doesn't provide with much scares, especially in subsequent playtroughs where you know their spawn locations. The other downside is the sanity mechanic which I never like in games when implemented in this way. It is just an annoyance. The story is alright but I consider the expansion far superior to the original game. The game is not long, you can beat it legit in under 4 hours but the highlight is early on in the game so the later parts become repetitive and kind of dissapointing compared to the first half. 
The expansion is perfect because it is quite short. in about 30min you can complete it and in that time everything that is great about the original is condensed here. The entirety of the game is tense and the story is even better im my opinion. Also it has the scariest chase sequence I've ever seen in any game. My butt was clenched so hard it resembled a neutron star during that part.

115180953.review:
While undeniably a pioneer in its time and highly influential, I wasn't all that impressed playing it today. The story wasn't that good, the enemies were very easy to deal with, the environments quickly grew bland and repetitive, and the sanity mechanic, while interesting initially, proved only a source of annoyance. It started off strong but was unable to keep the steam going until the end, or even the middle. Nothing lived up to the water creature segment and that came pretty early on. Also the puzzles and levels themselves gradually became simpler until by the end they were basically huge empty chambers. 

However I really liked the voice acting for Daniel, it was a pleasure listening to him narrate his diaries. The Shadow made for a cool but underutilized environmental hazard that I would have loved to see play a more active role in the game. 

Anyway, I think it's a must for any fan of horror, if only because it was the first big game of its kind and exploring the roots of a genre is always fun.

114397569.review:
Surrounded by the dark castle walls of Brennenburg, ridden with amnesia and haunted by an ominous shadow, you lie awake questioning your sanity and the daunting task ahead of you.

At release, Amnesia: The Dark Descent quickly became an iconic pillar of the "Let's Play" genre on YouTube, arguably making the platform's most notable stars such as PewDiePie and the like, famous. Aside from that, it had a massive impact on the horror genre that gave birth to a whole new generation of games in order to emulate its initial success. The formula was simple; strip all power from the player and force them to hide from the monsters. While most games bombard you with seeing the monster up close and personal, here you are penalized and thus the novelty is maintained. Although the foundation is simple, there is complexity in the mechanics that is best left for the player to discover.

A true horror in the making without expectation of big climactic cutscenes and endings; Amnesia instead, relies on sound, providing a permanent unsettling rumble as if the castle itself was moaning and groaning. The game reeks of atmosphere and capitalizes on continuous tension rather than jump scares. This is a must play.

I think what surprised me the most about the game was the variety of ways to solve the puzzles.
